DIV1.P: THE Perplex'd Lovers. A COMEDY. As it is Acted at the THEATRE-ROYAL in Drury-Lane, BY Her MAJESTY's Servants.

LONDON: rinted for Owen Lloyd, near the Church in the Temple; William Lewis, under Tom's Coffee-House in Covent-Garden; John Graves, next White's Chocolate-House in St. James-Street; and Tho. Har∣bin, in the lower Walk of the New-Exchange in the Strand. 1712.

DIV1.HEAD: TO Sir Henry Furnesse, Bar.
DIV1.P: I Hope, my being one of that Sex, which naturally Claim the Protection of Yours, will in some Mea∣sure excuse my Presumption in laying this follow∣ing Poem at your Feet. Tho' we Women are in∣capable of serving our Country in the Discharge of weighty Affairs, we would not be thought so insipid a Part of it, as not to admire those that are; among which None is more Conspicious than your self.

In You the Worthy Citizen, and Judicious Statesman, meet without the Vice of either; and from such Patriots of old, Rome became the Mistress of the World. The Good of Mankind seems your only Study: Your Fa∣therly Affection to your Children, Your generous Kind∣ness to your Servants, Your Sincerity and Openness to your Friends, Your compassionate Pity to the Poor, Your forgiving Temper towards your Enemies, and the true English Hospitality with which You treat all that have the Honour to know you, proclaim the Greatness of your Soul. Your honest Principle, and good Ma∣nagement of your Affairs at Home, commanded the Ho∣nour of your Bills abroad, and the Trust which lately was repos'd in you, was faithfully discharg'd to the Ho∣nour of Britain.

Then where shall the Weak appeal but to one so fam'd for Equity? And I hope that neither my Sex, nor my Cause, will render me unworthy of Your Protection. However worthless the following Pages may be in them∣selves, the Reason of their ill Success on the Stage is too notorious, and too long a Story to offer in this Epistle; tho' for the Satisfaction of my common Readers, I have thought fit to place it in a Preface. I confess, I cou'd never have thought it criminal to speak the Praises of those Heroes from a British Stage, to whom the greatest Part of Europe owes its Safety.

I am so truly sensible of the Weaknesses of my own Performance in this kind, that (however strong my in∣clinations were, or whatever I might have pretended to, as the Privilege of a Writer,) I shou'd not have presum'd to Address you, had not my Enemies done me the Ho∣nour to make me suffer in so glorious a Cause; I shall not however abuse the Liberty I now take, by pretend∣ing to give the World Your Character in a fulsome un∣skillful Panegyrick; but only wish, for the general Good of my Nation, that it abounded with such publick Spi∣rits as Your own; and that You long may Live, as now You are, the Honour of that City which You grace, as well as for the Interest and Glory of a free-born People; among which I beg leave to subscribe my self,

CLOSER.SIGNED: Your most Obedient Humble Servant, Susanna Cent-livre.

DIV1.HEAD: PREFACE.
DIV1.P:
I Am oblig'd to trouble my Reader with a Preface, that he may not be carried away with false Notions, to the Prejudice of this Play, which had the ill Fate to introduce a new Cu∣stom, viz. in being acted the first Day without an Epilogue: It seems the Epilogue design'd wou'd not pass; therefore the Mana∣gers of the Theatre did not think it safe to speak it, without I cou'd get it licens'd, which I cou'd not do that Night, with all the Interest I could make: So that at last the Play was forc'd to con∣clude without an Epilogue. Mr. Norris, who is an excellent Comedian in his way, was desired to speak six Lines Extempore, to entreat the Audience to excuse the Defect, and promised them an Epilogue the next Night; but they apprehending that that was the Epilogue design'd for the Play, were pleas'd to shew their Resentment. It is plain the want of an Epilogue caus'd the Hiss, because there had not been any thing like it during the whole action; but on the contrary a general Clap attended the Conclusi∣on of the Play. The next Day I had the Honour to have the E∣pilogue Licens'd by the Vice-Chamberlain, but by this time there was a Rumour spread about Town, that it was a notorious whig∣gish Epilogue; and the Person who design'd me the Favour of speaking it, had Letters sent her to forbear, for that there were Paries forming against it, and they advis'd her not to stand the Shock; here was a second Blow greater than the first: The sinking of my Play cut me not half so deep as the Notion I had, that there cou'd be People of this Nation so ungrateful as not to allow a single Compliment to a Man that has done such Wonders for it. I am not prompted by any private Sinister End, having never been oblig'd to the Duke of Marlborough, otherways than as I shar'd in common with my Country; as I am an English Women, I think my self oblig'd to acknowledge my Obligation to his Grace for the many Glorious Conquests he has attain'd, and the many Hazards he has run, to establish us a Nation free from the In∣sults of a Foreign Power. I know not what they call Whigs,
or how they distinguish between them and Tories: But if the De∣sire to see my Country secur'd from the Romish Yoke, and flourish by a Firm Lasting Honourable Peace, to the Glory of the best of Queens, who deservedly holds the Ballance of all Europe, be a Whig, then I am one, else not. I have Printed the Epilogue, that the World may judge whether 'tis such as has been represented▪ So much for that. Now I must acquaint my Reader, that I shall not pretend to vindicate the following Scenes, about which I took very little Pains, most of the Plot being from a Spanish Play, and assuring my self Success from Mr. Cyber's Approbation, whose Opinion was, that the Business wou'd support the Play; tho' Mr. Wilks seem'd to doubt it, and said, there was a great deal of Business, but not laughing Business; tho' indeed I cou'd not have dress'd this Plot with much more Humour, there being four Acts in the Dark, which tho' a Spanish Audience may readily conceive, the Night being their proper time of intreaguing; yet here, where Liberty makes Noon-day as easie, it perplexes the Thought of an Audience too much; therefore I shall take Care to avoid such Ab∣surdities for the future; and if I live I will endeavour to make my Friends amends in the next.

DIV1.HEAD: PROLOGUE. Spoken by Mr. BOOTH.
DIV1.L: TO entertain this bustling busie Age,
Our Author now brings Business on the Stage;
Sh plots, contrives, embroils, foments Confusion,
And et to Politicks makes not the least Allusion.
Business is now the A-la-mode Pretence,
All wou'd be Men of Business, and of Sense.
The uthless Rover, when with Caelia cloy'd,
Stil swears, that Business has his Time employ'd:
But when she sees him for another leave her,
Too late she finds her Business done for ever.
The for Business early leaves his Bed.
And Spouse▪ with other Business in her Head!
She rises early too by his Example,
Pretends some Law Case with spruce Counsellour Dimple,
And ets her Deary's Business done—i'th Temple.
The Size-box Spark,—his only Business lies
To his fair One's Passion in her Eyes.
The Ladies act their own, not mind our Parts,
The Business is, in looking out for Hearts.
Th sweet-condition'd Females of the Pit
Come not to us in Quest of Mirth, or Wit;
Nor they what becomes of a poor Play:
You know their Business lies another way.
To out my Business short then——I'm to pray,
Whilt re, you'd have no Business but the Play.
If in Attention your Applause is shewn,
ou'l do our Author's Business, and your own.

LIST.HEAD: MEN.
LIST.LABEL: Lord Richlove, in Love with Constantia.
Sir Roger Merryman, Father to Constantia and Belvill.
Colonel Bastion, in Love with Constantia.
Colonel Merryman, Father to Camilla.
Belvill, in Love with Camilla.
Timothy, Servant to Colonel Bastion.
Le Front, a French Vale de Chambre to the Lord Richlove.

LIST.HEAD: WOMEN.
LIST.LABEL: Constantia, in Love with Colonel Bastion.
Camilla, in Love with Belvill.
Florella, Maid to Constantia.

P.HI: The Time from Five in the Evening 'till Eight in the Morning.

SP.P: WHY you hungry Dog, is nothing to be minded but your Guts, Sirrah?

Why is it reasonable now, Colonel, that nothing shou'd be minded but your Love-Affairs 'till I am starv'd? in shot, Sir, I am no Soldier; if your Method and mine won't agree, why e'en let us part fairly.
Why what have you to complain of, Sirrah?

Oh! a multitude of things; since you have been ho∣nourably in Love, you are no more like the Man you were, than a Squib is to a Cannon; sometimes you walk so softly that my Feet freeze in my Shoes; then by and by so fast that a Highlander can't keep Pace with you—and I scarce get a good Meal in a Week; I must fast, because Love has ta'en away your Stomach, and the Devil a Bottle can I tick, because he has forsworn the Tavern. Aside. Besides, Sir, you load me with so many Secrets that I shall burst, or get my Bones broke one time or other; therefore, good Sir, discharge me.
Very sad Grievances indeed—So you are resolv'd to part with me then?
Yes really, Sir, without some Amendments on your side.
Come, what wou'd you have? let's hear.
Why, Sir, in the first place I wou'd have my Wages; there's a great deal due, Colonel.
How long have you serv'd me?
looks on a BookLet me see, I have serv'd you—— I have serv'd you just five Years, four Months, one Week, three Days, two hours, one Minute, and two Seconds, Sir.
You are very particular.

I love punctual dealings, Sir: Now my Wages comes to at six Pound per Annum, thirty two Pounds the five Years four Months, the odd Week two Shillings six Pence, the two Hours one Half-peny—as for the Half hour, one Minute, and two Seconds, I'll generously throw them into the Bargain. I scorn to treat a Gentleman dirtily.
You are wonderfully obliging.

Now, Sir, out of these thirty two Pounds three Shil∣lings and nine Pence Half-peny, I have receiv'd at several times▪ the full Sum of—nothing at all; so that there still remains due to me the aforesaid Sum, Colonel.
Very well, Sir, you shall be paid—These are the Extent of your Demands?
Nay hold there! these are but part of them, Sir.
Be brief then; what more?
Why, Sir, there is Board Wages for those Days I Eat nothing—my Pocket has no reason to enter into Alliance with my Stomach.
Oh these things shall be rectified. Come, you shant leave me.

Say you so, Sir? Why then you shall promise me three Meals a Day, and to intrust me with no Secret I may not tell the whole Town; for I Lye so much upon your account, Sir, that I am shrewdly afraid I shall never dye in my Bed.
Can you fall more honourably, Sirrah, than in defence of your Master's Secrets?

Faith, Sir, I desire to shake Hands with that kind of Honour; I heartily wish this honourable fit of Love may give
you an Aversion for the Sex; and then 'twou'd be some com∣fort to live with you.
That it has already: I believe I have done with Wo∣mankind.

How's that, Sir? Done with Womankind? Ods my Life, you are not struck with Death, are you? Or are you mar∣ried? No, no, that can't be; for then you'd have an Inclination to every Woman but your own Wife.
Yes, I am married to the Wars, and intend for Flan∣ders to Morrow.
Nay then, Sir, I am your most humble Servant. For Flanders quotha! that's out of the Frying-pan into the Fire: I have had enough of Flanders, I thank you.
There your Head won't be burthen'd with Secrets.

No, nor my Body burthen'd with my Head neither perhaps—I am afraid you and I must part at last, Colonel; for Flanders does not agree with my Constitution; the very Air of a Cannon Ball turns all my Blood in a Moment. But pray, Sir, with Submission, may I not know the Reason of this sudden Resolution? Is there no hopes of Madam Constantia then:

I fear not—I have a powerful Rival, Tim; my Lord Richove, her Servant assures me, has made her several Visits, encourag'd by her Father; then what may I not apprehend? he's a Lord, and she's a Woman; Grandeur and Titles charm that Sex beyond the power of Constancy and Love; her con∣cealing it from me, confirms she likes him. I'll visit her instant∣ly and take my leave, I shall judge by her Deportment if my Absence wou'd oblige her.
Nay, if he sees her there are some hopes of our stay∣ing in England yet—but Madam Camilla is still your Friend.

I think so, and the Door which opens out of her House into Constantia's Apartment undiscover'd, the only way by which I see her; go you to Camilla's, and with my humble Ser∣vice let her know I intend to wait on her immediately; and humble intreat Constantia may be there.
Yes, Sir.Exit.

How unequal are the Lots of Fate, and what innumera∣ble blessings wait on large Possessions? I have nothing but a faith∣ful Hours to ballance his Estate, and Title, no Gold to give in
Dowry with my Love, no Coach and Six to praunce it in the Ring, no Diamond Bait to glitter in the Box, no Thousand Pounds to hazard on a Card; this Sword is all my Fortune, and Love the only Jointure I can make.
Sir, Mrs. Camilla says, she'll inform her Cousin Con∣stantia this Minute.

SP.L: 'Tis well—
Now I the Crisis of my Fate shall try,
This Hour throws the Chance that bids me Live or Die.Ex.

SP.P: Oh Life, Life, sweet Heav'n give us Life, say I.Ex.

Come Cousin, prithee be chearful, dont let my Uncle's Proposal make you splenatick, we shall counter-plot 'em all, I warrant thee Girl — The Colonel's Sword is as long as my Lord's, and as good Mettle too, never fear it.

I hope I shall never see the Trial — I wou'd not have the Colonel know of his Lordship's Pretensions, for by my own Heart I judge the Pains that his would feel — the bare Suspi∣cion of a Rival wou'd distract me; and without Vanity, I be∣lieve our Flames are equal.
The Colonel's Pretensions are still a Secret to your Brother?

And still must be so — for you are not unacquainted with his Promise given to Sir Philip Gaylove — with whom he contracted a Friendship in his Travels— He is perfectly reco∣ver'd of that Illness which detain'd him behind my Brother at the Hague, and is expected in a few Days; now judge, if I have not a difficult Game to play, Camilla?
You have indeed, Constantia; but whilst I have Power to charm your Brother, you shall not want a Friend to send against that Blow — I never will be his, 'till thou are hap∣py.
I do believe thee; and were it not for thy indulging Kindness, my Brain had long e'er this been turn'd.
What think you of informing your Brother of my Un∣cle's Proceedings; I fancy he would rid you of his Lordship's Visits.

My Father strictly forbad me to mention that Affair; he knows what Regard my Brother has always to his Word, and how far the knowledge might transport him is uncertain; perhaps to an open breach of Duty, without the least Service to me; for were my Lord remov'd, What Defence have I a∣gainst my Brother's Friend?

What think you of marrying the Colonel privately? and going to Spain or Flanders with him for a Campaign or two? Time makes all things easie — You have Four Thou∣sand Pound that your Grand-father left you.
But in my Father's Hands.
Pho'! there may be Ways and Means found to get t out, my Life on't,—Ha! here's your Brother.
Bellvil! Unlucky Minute, which way shall I see the Colonel?Enter Bellvil.
Fear not, I'll pick a Quarrel with him, and set him go∣ing— So Sir, you are a Lover I hear!
Cou'd that News be a Stranger to you, Madam, that are so nearly concern'd in it?
Am I concern'd in your Passion for Belinda! whom you 'Squir'd to the Masquerade last Night?
Belinda! Pray who inform'd you that?
Those that knew you both, in spight of your Dis∣guise— I don't envy her Happiness, I assure you; and wou'd advise you to pay your Court there now, for I am not at Lei∣sure to receive your Visit.
You are mis-inform'd, upon my word, Madam; I nei∣ther waited on Belinda, nor saw the Masquerade last Night.

Your Judgment mis-informs you, if you imagine I'm to be convinc'd by all that you can say; and the best Excuse you can make, is to leave the Room—Perhaps I shall take a time to do you Justice, without putting you to the expence of Oaths to clear your self—go mind your Assignations.
This Proceeding is very odd, Camilla—Ha, who have we here? A new Lover? I have it now! my Visit was unsea∣sonable— You mistook, Madam, 'twas you that had Assig∣nations—Confusion—
What shall I do now? He is here.To Camilla▪

I must carry't off—Ho'now Sir! Who are you?
that comes so boldly up without Notice? Who wou'd you speak with?
Hey day! Why, what is the Woman bewitch'd?
With you, Madam—What is the Meaning of this— Constantia's Brother! Mum! I must not seem to know my Love.Aside.
Col. Bastion! You surpriz'd me, really I did not know you—
These great Ladies have very short Memories.

Colonel, have you any private Business with this Lady? I am one of the Civilest Rivals you ever met with—I'll retire into the next Room till you have deliver'd it—But then must beg a word with you my self.
Sir! It is a Secret of no such Importance I assure you, as you imagine— All the Affairs I have with this Lady, may be done in publick.
Methinks you usurp a Liberty, unbecoming a Depen∣ding Lover; be gone and see my Face no more.
Nay, now Camilla, I must interpose! That Task's too hard to suit my Brother's Love—Tho' I wish him ge on any Terms.Aside.
Madam let me become a Mediator, perhaps my Business may relate to him as much as you.
What in the Name of Goodness is he about to say now?
Sure he won't tell him he is in love with his Sister!
To morrow I intend for Harwich, in order to Embrk for Flanders; if you have any Recommendations thither I shall deliver them with Pleasure—ha! Constantia changes Col.
For Flanders, oh! my Heart.Ade
If this be all! I ask your Pardon Colonel, and shll give you the Trouble of a Letter to a Friend of mind in Lif.
And I, of one to my Brother, if you'll let your Ser∣vant call for it an Hour hence. Courage Cousin, this is ok a sudden Thought of the Colonel's to take off Bellvil's Suspion.
In the mean time if you'll do me the Honour, Col, I'll dispatch mine over a Bottle—I hope you'll have a Letter Opinion of me, Madam, when I see you next.
According to the Humour you find me in, Bellvil.
Ill follow you, Sir: Tim, wait for the Lady's Letter; and, do you hear? be sure you bring me word how I shall see Constantia again.Aside to Tim.
A pox of this Letter for me, now shan't I get one drop of the Wine. Pray, Madam, be as quick as you can, my Ma∣ster will be very impatient.
Does your Master really go for Flanders, Tim?

Faith I fear so, Madam: But I have no Commission to answer Questions; not do I believe it possible to know my Ma∣ster's Mind three hours together; but if you have any Commands for him, Madam, I am your faithful humble Servant to deliver 'em. But don't let me wait I beg you, Madam; for to tell you the truth, I shall forfeit a Bottle, if I meet not a Friend of mine here by in a quarter of an hour.

Well, not to detain you from your Friend. Tim. take this Ky, and bid your Master meet me in the Garden half an Hour hence; and least your Bottle should be in Danger—there is something to defray the Expence.Gives him Mony.
Good, I like a Person of a clear Understanding; she took the Hint—Madam, I flie to execute your Orders.Exit.
Now! If he shou'd be commanded away, Camilla?
Why, then were I in thy Place, Girl, I'd pluck up a Courage, pack up my Awls and march with him.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE changes to the Outside of a Garden in the Street.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Lord Richlove and Florella at several Doors.

SP.P: Is your Lordship alone?
I am. Florella! what hast thou to tell me? Dost thou Constantia inclining to my Love? How did she relish her Frs Proposal?
As sick People do the News of Death.
Ha! sayst thou? How did she treat me in my Absence? I know thou art her Confident, and shalt tell me all.

I have a very great Deference for your Lordship, and much esteem for my Lady—but my Lord, Self-interest governs the World; if I favour your Lordship I shall disoblige my Lady, and lose my Place; Service is no Inheritance, my Lord—
I understand you—and assure you whatever Disco∣veries you make to me shall turn to your Advantage; this to confirm it.Gives her a Purse.

Ay, there's some sense in this; who wou'd not speak for a Man of Quality? that paultry Colonel never gave me a∣bove half a Guinea—Your Lordship is so extremely good, that I declare I can refuse you nothing; I wish my Lady wou'd say so, my Lord, but 'tis impossible, for she hates you, and vow'd to me this Morning, as I was reading her a Lecture in praise of your Lordship, if there were never another Man in the Universe, she'd dye a Maid, and lead you know what, my Lord, before she'd wed you.
Is her Aversion so strong, say'st thous? perhaps she loves elsewhere?
I have nothing to say to that, my Lord; but if you please I can put you where you may inform your self.
If thou can'st do that thou bindest me ever thine.
This Key opens the back Gate of our Garden, whi∣ther she it just now gone.
To meet her Lover, ha?
I never answer Questions of this kind with my Tongue, my Lord.
I conceive you, adieu.Exit.

I want only to serve some Favourite at Court to be a great Woman—twenty pieces added to my Fortune! this is no ill Evening's Work: What Advantages the Donor proposes to himself, I neither know, nor care. I have put them together, let 'em come off as they can.Exit.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE the Inside of the Garden.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Colonel Bastion, Constantia, and Timothy as a distance.

SP.P: I am glad you had an Excuse so ready before my Bro∣ther, or we had been undone; but that going for Flanders sav'd all—What will you do with his Letter?
Deliver it, as I promised.
Deliver it! are you in earnest? Must I lose you then so soon?
I fear you do not think it soon enough, Constantia.
What do you mean, Bastion? Why this Indifference? Ha my too much Fondness made you Cool, or have your Eye ta'en in some other Love, and now wou'd throw your Guilt on me?

I wish you be not guilty— Oh Constantia, has thy Reason never call'd thy Choice in question, by representing things above my Sphere? Will not the Pageantry of Fortune aba thy Love to me, and make me seem unworthy of you?

He talks as if he knew my Lord's Design. Why do you suspect me? In what Action, since our first Acquaintance, have I betray'd a Soul so mercenary? Think you my Taste so vited, that like common Wretches, I cou'd love for Gold? No, Love is a free-born Passion of the Mind, not to be pur∣chas'd at a sordid Price—Those that can make their Bodies subservient to their Interest, were ne'er acquainted with that Noble Passion, but like the Brutes submit to Nature's Call, unknowing of Love's mighty Excellence.
Oh, thou hast clear'd my Doubts so fully now, that no one Fear remains—Pardon my Jealousies, since they proved from Love. Hark! What Noise is that?
I hope my Brother has not miss'd me, and come to seek me in the Garden— I'll step to the Parlour Door to avoid being surpriz'd; if all be safe, I'll return in a Moment—Ex.

STAGE.HI: A noise of a Key in a Door.

SP.P: Sir, Sir, Sir, afore George, there's a Key in the Door, we e certainly discover'd— and shall be apprehended for There; a Pox take all Intreaguing, I say.
Peace, you cowardly Dog, or I'll cut your Throat.
Look you there now, when I am running the Danger of the Gallows for him, he'd cut my Throat for Satisfaction; the would not serve one of these Traders in Blood.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Lord Richlove; speaks as he Enters.

SP.P: Wait you without.
Ha! My Lord Richlove! Amazement! How came he by a too? Sure he had it not from her.

DIV3.STAGE: Re-enter Constantia, mistaking the Lord for the Colonel, and runs into his Arms.

SP.P: There's no Danger, my Life—But speak low lest they should hear us, and our Meeting be prevented for the future.
What's that of meeting for the future?
Oh Transport! oh Extasic! my charming Angel— Humph, 'tis plain she loves——and did expect her Lover here.
Hell and Furies! in Raptures?
My Lord Richlove! which way got your Lordship hi∣ther?—Distraction, what shall I do now?
Did not you expect me, Fairest?
Expect him, oh perfidious Woman!
I expect you, Insolence!
What! then I'm not the happy Man to whom you flew! why do you tremble so! oh let me dwell upon these Lips whose every touch runs thro' my Heart with Pleasure.
What shall I say, if I cry out my Bastion will be found, were he away I'd make an Example of this Monster.Aside.
She's conscious of her Wrongs to me, and whispers out her words, least I shou'd hear her: Oh thou Serpent o thy kind!Aside.
Have I too suddenly surpriz'd thee? Come let's retire to this Alcove, where in my Arms thou shalt recover Breath, and hear me tell how much I love thee.
Away my Lord, and leave the Garden, and force me not to examine by what Authority you treat me thus.
Now she exalts her Voice to blind my Rage, convey him hence, and so deceive me on—but I can bear no moe— Draw, my Lord, and give an injur'd Lover Satisfaction.Draw.
Draw! who are you, Sir?
Ah! Heav'n defend my Bastion, ah! help, Mur∣der.
Thus I inform you.
Thus I return it.They fight.
Murder! Murder! Murder!Tim. draws and ft against the Wall, and cries Murder all the ile.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Footmen to the Lord at one Door, Sir Roger Mrrar, Bellvil and Florella at the other. The Colonel disarms the Lord, and throws him his Sword.

SP.P: There's your Sword, my Lord—when next we preserve it better—Come along, you timorous Rascl.
Ay, with all my Heart, Lights and Liver.Ex.
Murder cry'd in our Garden?
Secure him, Slaves.To his Fos
Secure who, my Lord?
The Gentleman that fought me.
We see no Body, my Lord—ho, yes, here he is.
Villains hold off, or I'll stick some of you.
What! my Son assassinated by Ruffians? Within there, where are all my Servants? My Lord Richlove! how came your oship here? Not a word of your Love to my Daughter, my Lord.Aside to Lord.
If your Lordship discovers me I'm undone.Aside to him.
My Lord Richlove! and Murder cry'd—Where is my Sister, Florella?
In her Chamber, Sir.
What Adventure brought your Lordship into our Gat∣

Now dare not I accuse my Rival, least I betray my se—Why, Sir, coming by your Garden Wall here, I to jostie a Gentleman that had got a Lady there it seems, who immediately lugg'd out upon me; the place being narrow, I thought to clap my Back against the Wall, but happening up∣on the Garden Door, it suddenly gave way, and in I fell— my Antagonist supposing he had kill'd me fled——the Woman shrick —my Servants roar'd out Murder—and I call'd out to him; which noise I suppose brought you, Gentlemen.
An admirable Story.Aside.
This may be true, 'tis probable.Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rog.
SP.P: I hope your Lordship has receiv'd no hurt.
Not at all, Sir Roger—Let me see you by and by orner of the Street, Florella.Aside to her.
Dpend upon it, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir .
SP.P: Will your Lordship please to walk into my House, treet be clear? the noise may have alarm'd the Neigh∣bourhood.
I'm engag'd to the Play, Sir Roger——you'll excuse this ple which I have accidentally given you: Gentlemen humble Servant.Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir
SP.P: I am glad your Lordship is safe, the trouble is no∣thing.
ake not these Court Weasels sauntring about our House, the Fly is seldom lucky where they frequent.Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rog.
SP.P: I suspect his Lordship had another End in coming here, tho' I know not how he got into the Garden; my Daughter was the Cause—Oh that stubborn Baggage, wou'd she but listen to his Love, she might make her Father a great Man.

Q.L: Beaut has many Fortunes made at Court,
And many Title thanks a Woman for'tExeunt.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I. SCENE the Street.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Lord Richlove and Le Front.

SP.P: ME Lor, you be more dejected for dis Lady, dn I ever saw your Lordship for any Lady in me Life.
Because there is more difficulty in obtaining this Lady than ever I met before—I am an honourable Lover now, Le Front, and a Slave to one that hates me.
How does your Lordship know she hates you? Wo∣men are very cunning me Lor, and when day say day hate a, begar day love best sometimes, me know dat very well.
But I am convinc'd she loves another.
O de Divel! dat is another thing Mafoy.

By the help of her Maid, whom I expect here present∣ly, I got admittance into her Garden, and surpriz'd her with her Lover, but was so unfortunate not to discover who he was— and tho' my Passion is authoriz'd by her Father, I forese s never will be mine.

Me Lor, may I ask a you one Question? vil nothing but Marriage cure your Love? have a you take a one surfeit of variety? and must a you take a de course of Physick for life, me Lor? ah! a Vise is one dam bitter Pill, dat vil never out your Stomach 'till Death, begar.
But Love makes that Bitter sweet, Le Front.

Love! begar, if your Lorship were one very poor I shou'd believe you—because de pavre Man is always very much in Love with de rich Lady—but de Gens de Quality— never, me Lor, never—day don't mind Cupid, begar their gr. Figure scorn de little sneaking Bastard.
And the rich Ladies scorn poor Men, I'm sure.

Sometime, me Lor. sometimes; but there be some ge∣nrs Ladies that like a de hansome young Fellow very much. he was very well once wid the rich Widow, me visit her every D, me stay 'till one, two, three, four de Clock every Morning me dance vid her, me sing vid her—me kiss her so warn, so warn, so warmly, as me please begar, and me swear me love her very much, because she was very rich, me Lor, and she love a me ve∣ry much too.
How came you did not marry her then?
Ah dat was deting▪ my Lord, begar she no want Mar∣ri—an de dam cunning Divel knew I wanted noting else —
Oh! You shou'd have ta'en an Opportunity to prove her Per was your only Aim.

Oh begar me give her proofe enough of dat, she let me do ervting begar me ask —oh she lov'd to be tickled my Lord, b sear'd to be expos'd into Manage—she lov'd a me Person dear∣y, dearly—but begar she lov'd her Mony better. She take one Chamber for me in her House begar, to lye at Bed, and Board, but wou'd not go mafoy, me love Marriage my Lord—me no de Stallion, begar.
And so she jilted you.
Even so me Lor—now had me been a your Lorship, me shou'd have had her vid a wet Finger, begar; for de Men of Quality may have any Lady mafoy.

You have a wrong Notion, as to all Women, Le Front; a Woman can't be virtuous that gives a Man such Encou∣rgent as your Widow did you—for a virtuous Woman will not ve a second Visit from the Person she has no Design up∣on— ou'd Constantia give me such Liberty, I wou'd not fear Poon one way or other.
Nor need you yet, me Lor, if Possession will do your afir—
What say'st thou?
Mony, my Lor, Mony vill do all Tings,
Away Fool, she wants it not.

But her Maid——me Lor——her Maid—ah! how many ritty Tings de Maid can do—she can put a your Lor∣ship de Bed-Chamber of her Mistress, and hide a you there 'till Midnight; then you cou'd creep a softly, softly, softly, to de
Bed-side, lift a de Cloaths gently, gently, gently, steal into de Bed silently, take a de Lady in your Arms tenderly, and when your Lorship have her there assair & fait, begar, ha, ha.
Ha! The bare Imagination gives me Pleasure; thou hast inspir'd me with a way to revenge my self of her Disdain. Wel∣come Dear—
Florella, in thee lies all my Hope: Thou canst inform me, who is the happy Man? I prithee let me know my Rival.
To what end, my Lord?
Leave that to me.

You must pardon me there my Lord, I'll do any thing to serve your Lordship, that wears no Face of Guilt, because I see your Lordship can carry a thing off at a Pinch—but won't absolutely betray the Secrets of my Lady neither; in short, my Lord, the Knowledge won't advance your Sute, and he may he a Chance for his Life as well as you—Let this suffice, he is no Coward — for Fighting is Meat, Drink and Clothes to , therefore think if I can serve you any other way, my Lord.
Yes, one way thou canst—If thou'lt convey me pri∣vately into Constantia's Bed-Chamber to Night.
Into her Bed-Chamber, my Lord! I fear your Dign mayn't be honourable—and I wou'd not have a Hand in my La∣dy's Ruin for the World.

Nor wou'd I attempt it —my only Reason for it is, that there I may have an Opportunity to declare my Mind, and Prudence will oblige her to hear me —least the malicies World reflect upon her Conduct — Come you shall do this.

STAGE.HI: Putting a Ring upon her Finger.

SP.P: I think your Lordship has hid a Spell upon me, I have no Power to deny whatever you ask me. An Hour hence ex∣pect me here, my Lord.
I will.
Odd methinks my Finger becomes a Diamond Ring as well as my Lady's.Exit.
Now Loves great Goddess smile on my Design, And all the Glory of Success be thine.Exit.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE changes to Camilla's House.

SP.P: Which way got his Lordship into the Garden?
Nay Heav'n knows, nor how the Colonel made his E∣scape, or if he lives; oh I dread your Maid's Return.
Lives I warrant him, or we had seen Timothy e'er this.
The Colonel will wait on you immediately, Madam.
Very well, wait without to receive him.
Madam your Cousin Bellvil is coming up.
What shall I do now?
Here, here, step into this Closet, I'll find some Pre∣tence to get him away.Exit Constantia into the Closet.

What the Devil did this Wench run back so fast at Sight of me for—Ha! sure I saw some Body whip into that Closet —Well, Camilla, what Humour is your Ladyship in at pre∣sent? Dispos'd to be angry still, or how?
No, I think I have a Mind to be pleas'd Cousin, if you don't cross it; nay, I am in so good an Humour, that I could find in my Heart to ask your Pardon for my last Quarrel with you.
So, now she's upon the wheedle—There is certainly some body in that Closet—Prithee what Reason had you set that unjust Accusation, Camilla?

My dear inquisitive Lover, be not too curious to pry in∣to the Reasons of Women— We have either too many for your Knowledge, or too few for your Quiet; you shou'd never hik us in the wrong before Marriage, tho' we seldom think you in the right after it.
A frank Confession; but my Humour is just the Reverse, I can see every Fault in a Mistress, but none in a Wife.
That is, you won't think a Wife's Actions worth Re∣ard. The first Month takes off the Sting of your Appetite, and er after you become a meer Drone.
Prithee try me, Camilla, and from Experience admonish our Sex, and don't let false Notions prevail to the Prejudice of .
I'll consider on't; come shall we take a turn in the Gar∣den? You promis'd to teach me the last new Song.
I'll go into your Closet, and write it down for you.
No, no, no, no, you must not go into the Closet.
Why so? Have you a Spark there?
Look ye there now, you will be asking Questions; upon Honour there is no Male thing in that Closet; will that suffice?
Then why am I forbid to enter?

Nay if you doubt what I say, you'll give me Cause to suspect your Love: There's the Key, satisfie your Curiosity; but from this Moment depend upon it, my House shall ne'er receive you as a Lover more; then take your Choice, the Closet with∣out me, or me without the Closet.
Too well you know your Power, Camilla! I'll wait you to the Garden.
So now I like you, learn to be tractable, and then one may endure you for a Husband.Exeant.

DIV3.STAGE: Constantia comes out of the Closet.

SP.P: I'm glad he's gone, my Heart went pit-a-pat when she offer'd him the Key.
My dear Bastion! My Heart has had a thousand Fears for thee.
For my Lord Richlove you mean, Madam; I had the Advantage, but spared him for your sake, since I could not pierce his Breast without wounding yours.
How ill does this Language become a Lover's Month.

And how ill does your Carriage become a virtuous Wo∣man? S'death, could you not be content to receive his Vsits in private, but you must make me Spectator of your Treachery? Must you triumph to gratifie your Pride?
I scorn your Accusations—since you can entertain Thought to the Prejudice of my Virtue, you are unworthy of my Justification.

I shall not put you to the trouble of an Excuse, Ma∣dam. Laying it upon the Carelessness of Servants leavig open the Door, and his stumbling that way by accident, wou'd be no Purpose, because I know he had the same Passport with self, a Key; and who shou'd give it him but you, and as such Juncture too, you tim'd it to a Minute.

Ha! a Key, which way got he a Key.—Ungrateful; have I refus'd that Lord you mention, when by my Father's strict Commands preferr'd! and ran the Hazard of a Parent's Hae for thee? For thee who dares to upbraid me thus—but thou hast cur'd my Folly; yes, I will tear thee from my Heart, and throw thee as a worthless Trifle by; but I owe so much to my Fame, to clear thy gross Mistake how my Lord came by that Key—I know not, nor of his coming to the Garden; or if I e'er admitted one Thought, that cou'd be favourable to his Love, may soul Contagion sieze me; but what your Usage, may inspire me with, Time will produce, for from this Hour I'll never—

Falling on his Knees.Oh hold, I conjure thee; keep back that hasty Resolution, my charming Angel; forgive the Ex∣cess of faithful Love. My abject Fortune, when compar'd with his, wakd a thousand racking Cares, and fear of losing what my Soul ores, transported me to Madness; pardon me now, and if I e'er offend again—

I must again forgive you, is it not so? Why dost thou stdy to destroy my Quiet? Is Jealousie so requisite to prove we Love? No sure: Love is a soft and gentle Joy, and shou'd be fond∣led like a render Infant; the rude surly Gusts of Passion, like Eastern Winds, destroy it in the Bud.
Have I not Reason for my Fears, Constantia? when thy Father and thy Brother are both against me?
No, not if all the World combin'd, whilst thou hast me.

Thou matchless Woman, how shall I requite thee? Life will be too short to do it. But when wilt thou compleat my Joys, and give thy Person with thy Heart? Constantia, I dread the Ar∣rival of thy Brother's Friend; not that I fear thy Change— but he will importune thee, thy Father will command thee, and 'twill he difficult to find Objections against both; but when we are , and all Arguments fail to rid thee of their Sollicita∣tions, that Discovery sets thee free at once.
Have Patience but a while, my Love; I wou'd not do an Act of ch Importance without my Father's Consent, if possible.
How dost thou hope to gain it?
That I must think of.
But then thy Brother!
His Love to Camilla will befriend us there, she's ours you know, and will scruple nothing for our Interest.
She is indeed a generous Friend, cou'd she not change your Brother's Purpose?

She has not attempted it, and the Reason she gives for it is, shou'd he suspect her to favour any private Inclination of mine, he wou'd certainly prevail with my Father to send me into the Country; which wou'd not only intirely prevent her be∣ing serviceable to us, but infallibly force me into the Arms of his Friend: For tho' my Father's Pride inclines to my Lord, yet his Tenderness to my Brother wou'd not suffer him to contra∣dict his Purpose.

Do not defer my Happiness, Constantia—I'll be Father, Brother, Husband to thee; if thy Love does equal thy Expressi∣ons, what should deter thee from my Arms? True Love re∣quires small Subsistence, our Constancy shall brave all Turns of Fate, and spight of Malice we will bless each other.

Duty commands me to try the gentlest way; I wou'd a∣void all Violence with a Father; but this be certain of, my Love; not even he shall alter my Resolves, or bribe me to forgo my Bastion; let him dispose of all his hoorded Wealth, that which my Uncle left me must be mine, and that with Love will be suf∣ficient for us. If abandon'd by my Friends in England, then we will seek for more in foreign Nations. Whilst I have thee, I I never shall repine, or wish for ought beyond thy Power to give.

SP.L: And my Ambition's bounded in these Arms,
Every Good that Nature can bestow
And every Charm is center'd sure in thee.
This single Room to me contains all Joy,
'Tis the wide World, and all I wish is here.Embraces her.
Camilla's Maid within.Who's that gone up Stairs?

SP.P: within.'Tis I, I dropt one of my Gloves above.
Ah Heav'n, I hear my Brother's Voice —If I seen with thee we are ruin'd—which way shall I avoid him?
Ha! What shall we do—humph! I have it; give me your Mask, and go you down the back way, leave me to make my own Retreat.Exit Constantia. He puts on the M

Now for the Closet! Ha! z'death what Woman's th that with such Care avoids me? it must be sure my Sister— ha, a Man too, nay then 'tis past a Doubt— and Camil
must be privy to their meeting; 'Sdeath, am I impos'd upon? But I will be satisfy'd.Going and Bast. turns quick upon him.
No Passage this way, Sir.
Mask'd! What are you, Sir? Some Ruffian come to Rob the House, ha? I must and will pass this way.
You neither must nor shall, Sir, if you go to that.
'Sdeath, Sir, unmask and tell me so, I'll not dispute it with a Villain.
I am no Villain, Sir, yet shan't unmask, for some pri∣vate Reasons; but if you'll suspend your Curiosity and retire, you shall have the Satisfaction of a Gentleman to Morrow where you please.
Dam to Morrow, this to thy Heart.Draws.
That's your mistake, Sir.Draws and drives him out.
You heedless Slut, why did you let him go up Stairs?
He was half way up before I heard him, Madam.

Ha! what Noise is that? Sure I heard the clashing of Swords—I hope he did not meet the Colonel and Constantia— Again! bless me my Heart trembles as if my Life were going; if I shou'd assist their Loves, 'till I destroy my own now. With∣in there, fly and part 'em.
Part who, Madam?

SP.L: Any Body you find engag'd.
Ha! Murder! what shall I do!
Colonel, Is it you? What's the matter?

SP.P: I have not time to tell you, Madam, but beg you'd hide me somewhere, or 'tis impossible to escape Bellvil's know∣ledge.
Here, here, step thro' this Door into Constantia's A∣partment, 'till the hurry be over.Exit Bast.
What noise of Murder's that, Bellvil? You have not kill'd any Body, have you?
I suppose you know to the contrary, Madam; for if my sight deceiv'd me not, the Spark return'd into your House.
What Spark do you mean? I fear he has discover'd poor Constantia.Aside.
Had not your Servants interpos'd, I shou'd have spoil'd his making Love for a Month perhaps; but if I find him—
Find who?
Ay, that's what I want, I wou'd know who he is.

Nay if you are ignorant of that, all's safe—This fiery Temper of yours, Bellvil, is an excellent Qualification for a Husband; are you jealous of every Man you meet? What In∣solence is this? Must my House be search'd whenever you please? I am my own Mistress, I hope, before Marriage, 'tis enough for you to Lord it after.
I scorn to insult an Enemy, much less my Mistress; but where my Honour is concern'd, give me leave to be as careful as I can.
Your Honour! What mean you? Can you suspect me of any Design against your Honour?

Oh Camilla! thou'rt no Stranger to my Meaning; tell me, what close design does my Sister drive in your House? for I am certain 'twas Constantia that you conceal'd within that Clo∣set, and whoever this Fellow is, was with her: Confusion! shall an obscure Rascal privately supplant my Friend, to whom my Word is pass'd? No, if she refuse my Choice, by Hell she ne'er shall Marry.

How! Bellvil? wou'd you presume to prescribe your Sister's Fate, and wrest the power of Heav'ns Decree? tho' I know nothing of Constantia's Mind, I dare believe she scorns your base Description, she'll never wed below her Birth.
Then she does love it seems! and you are in the Secret, say who is this mighty Gentleman?

You are mad your self, and wou'd have others so; be∣cause I won't believe she loves below her self, does it therefore follow that she must love indeed? I tell you again, that I know nothing of her; the Lady you saw was another Friend of mine, and she was undress'd, and beg'd she might not be seen, which was the reason of her running into the Closet; the Gentleman was a Stranger to me.

Methinks this sounds just like Invention, but I love too well to break with her, and she's but too sensible of that.Aside.
Well I will inquire no farther—'Sdeath, but the Mask— Why was he Mask'd?
Mask'd! was he Mask'd, say you? doubtless he had his Reasons for it; every Man to his way, you know.
If his way lies not towards my Sister, Success to him; if it does, let him look to't.

SP.L: Envy'd Lovers often thrive the best:
Lt Men pursue their strictest jealous Care,
We Women still can match 'em to a Hair.Exeunt.

SP.P: HERE are so many People about this House, that I cannot possibly get out; and if Camilla shou'd have no opportunity to aprize Constantia of my being here, she may be frighted: Ha! I hear some Body coming this way, I'll step aside and listen, perhaps it may be she.
Softly, my Lord.
peeping.My Lord: What do I hear?
The next is my Lady's Bed-chamber—you'll be sure to be civil——
Damnation—her Bed-chamber.

SP.L: Oh! You may depend upon that, Child.
There, Florella.Gives her Mony.

SP.P: Florella! ha!
Go, go, go, wish me success, Wench.Exit.

That I do with all my Heart, my Lord—Well, am nor I a Jade now, to put a Man into my Lady's Bed-chamber without her Knowledge? But shou'd not I be a Fool to refuse a Diamond Ring and two Broad pieces? ay certainly—I have only drawn the Wine, she may chuse to Drink—besides 'tis a way to exercise her Virtue—no Body can boast of Ho∣nesty 'till they are try'd—I once thought my self proof
against Temptation, but the dear, bewitching Gold has caught me; and the best way to reconcile it to my Conscience, is not to be too inquisitive into the Reasons by which I rise.Ex.

'Zdeath, introduc'd by her Maid! Hell and Furies, it cannot, surely, be by her Command; No, I Dream, and this is all Illusion; Constantia's mine, wholly mine, Chast as the New∣born Day, or Buds of Roses, e'er the Winds have kiss'd 'em; This must be Treachery, the Maid's corrupted— Why did I not seize and drag her to Constantia? Hold, that might have furnish'd her with an Excuse, and help'd to deceive my self— for she may be False! Who can judge the Heart of Woman— Here will I stay and wait the Event, Ha! She comes. Enter Constantia with a Candle. I Tremble, lest she shou'd be Guilty.

I admire I hear not from my Cousin—Pray Heav'n he be well, and 'scap'd unseen by Bellvil. Oh Repose! thou Stranger to the Breasts of Lovers, when wilt thou return to bless me? An unusual Heaviness sits on my Spirits, as if some mighty Danger threatned me—If Bastion's safe, I care not what it be, for nought has Pow'r to shock my Soul wherein he's not concern'd—Camilla promis'd to pass the Evening with me, I wish she'd come, I'll go into my Chamber, and read something in Cowley.Ex.Bast. comes forward.

SP.L: She's gone: Now hold my Heart, and let my Ears in∣form me?
If Innocent, in her Defence I'll draw;
If not, my own Revenge shall be my Law.Ex.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE draws, and discovers Constantia reading▪ Lord Richlove enters softly behind her.

SP.P: Reads.I try'd if Books cou'd cure my Love, but found, Love made 'em Nonsense all—
Reads over her Shoulder.I apply'd Receipts of Bu∣siness to my Wound, but stirring did the Pain recall——
Bless me! Who are you?Rising up.
One that adores the fair Constantia.
Astonishing! My Lord Richlove in my Chamber? How got your Lordship Admittance here?
Love, Love, my Charmer; I find you know his Pow'r, therfore cannot be surpriz'd at his Liberty,
Insolence! Does this Action become a Man of Ho∣nour, my Lord? Leave me instantly—I command you.

This Action becomes a Lover, Madam, and he that loves like me, is unable to quit the Object of his Wishes— Thus low, upon my Knees, I ask your Pardon, for intruding on your Privacies, and beg you'd favourably hear what I have to offer.
Your Proceeding wears so ill a Face, my Lord, you cannot hope, with Favour, to be heard— Coming like a Thief upon me, is not sure the way.
The only way that I could think of, Madam, to offer you a Heart intirely devoted to your Service; and with it all that I am Master of; so well I love, you shall be Mistress of my self and Fortune.

I thank your Lordship— But that you may not be deceiv'd, observe me well—Were you Master of the spacious Globe, and at your Feet the trembling World bow'd down, I shou'd contemn all Offers you cou'd make, and with the same Coldness hear your Tale of Love. I'm not dispos'd to Marry.
How! Not dispos'd to Marry? Is there then a Hap∣py Man to whose Arms you'd fly without it? I can dispence with Ceremony too, and be content to share with him your Fa∣vours.Approaching her.
What mean you, my Lord?
What did you mean, Madam, when you slew into my Bosom in the Garden to Night? You did not design that kind Embrace for me.Lays hold of her.
Stand off! and touch me not— The Man that I mi∣stook thee for, (for now I will own I love) holds more Virtues than all thy Ancestors could boast; and were he here, you durst not thus affront me.
Durst not— By all the Injuries of slighted Love, I would enjoy thee even before his Face; Nay, struggle not, proud Beauty.
By Heav'n she's spotless! Oh my kind Stars! This was a lucky Opportunity.
Help, a Rape! a Rape!Struggles with him.
Ravisher, let go the Lady, and take thy just Reward from me.Draws,
Bastion here!Accidentally throws down the Candle.
Who are you, Sir? that dare to interfere with my Concerns. Draws. I am glad the Light's out, my Business is not to fight here, but make my Escape, if possible—
I answer Questions thus, Sir; where are you?
Ah, Murder, Murder — Defend my Love, ye Pow'rs!
Ha! a Candle! If you are a Gentleman, meet me in the Street immediately, and there I'll give you Satisfaction.Ex.
I'll follow you—Going,
Not for the Universe—Stops him.
What's the matter here? Was not that my Lord?
It was—Ha! the whole House is alarm'd, what shall I do? If Bastion's found I am undone.
Here, here, Colonel, this Door, you know; secures your Retreat back into my House —
As you prize my Life, do not follow him; an Hour hence I'll quit this House, and thro' Camilla's meet thee, be ready to receive me.
Be certain of it; till when, thou Charmer of my Soul, Farewel.Exit.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Sir Roger, Bellvil, and Servants.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rog.
SP.P: What's the matter, Daughter?
Did I not hear Murder cry'd? Constantia.
Yes; and had you been a little quicker, might have seen the Cause; by what Contrivance I know not, but my Lord Richlove was here in your Sister's Chamber.
My Lord Richlove in my Sister's Chamber!
And with foul Intentions too—Oh Sir, if you e∣steem me as a Sister, or you Sir, as a Child of yours, relieve me from this Brutal Passion.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rog.
SP.P: Brutal Passion! you Amaze me, I am sure he told me his Love was honourable.
Told you, Sir? Why, has he declar'd his Love to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rog.
SP.P: Why, yes, Bellvil, I must confess he did ask my leave to court her— And I cou'd not refuse a Man of his Birth, and Fortune, rudely.
'Sdeath! then you encourag'd him!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rog.
SP.P: Not absolutely encourag'd him—But if she cou'd have lik'd him—He's a Lord, you know!
Dam his Title—

But less honourable than a Footman, he dragg'd me round the Room, and vow'd Revenge upon my Virtue; my Cries brought Camilla to my Aid, at sight of whom he fled, or Heav'n knows what I had suffer'd from his Violence.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rog.
SP.P: Say'st thou so! 'Od I'll banish him my House.
Confusion! Banish him the House! I'll banish him the World, if I can meet him.Ex.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rog.
SP.P: And I'll send him word so this Moment—At∣tempt the Honour of my Daughter!En.
Bellvil, methinks, left the Room abruptly; I wish the Consequence prove not fatal.
I hope he will not find him—
Pray Heav'n he may not. Which way got my Lord in, think ye?
I cannot guess—Nor by what Miracle Bastion came to my Relief.

I can unriddle that part, I let him in thro' the little Door, to avoid Bellvil's seeing him—You'll excuse me, dear Constantia, I am under some Uneasiness for Bellvil, and must endeavour to clear my Suspicion.Ex.

SP.L: Success attend thee—Here is no Safety left for me,
I'll take Security in my Bastion's Arms.
His constant Heart shall all my Fears remove,
And now my Duty shall give place to Love.Ex.

SP.P:
What a cursed Shambling Life is this of a Footman? Faith! think those Honest Gentlemen perfectly in the right that have forsworn the Livery, and set up their Coaches— E'gad my Legs are fall'n away to Catsticks——I was forc'd to have the Waist-band of my Breeches taken in a Quarter of a Yard—Sure Love is catching, for I am grown a meer Skeleton, and in a few Days more I shall be taken for my Ma∣ster—'Tis a little hard tho', when I say I want my Dinner, he
replies, I have no Stomach yet—and when I say I am Dry— he says, there is Tea in the Pot, drink that, 'twill quench your Thirst—and when I am so Sleepy I can't stand, he sends me upon the Scout—Here I'm to watch the opening of that Door— for it seems this Night he is to carry off his Mistress— Wou'd he had her once, for this course of Life is very contrary to my Appetite—Suppose now I shou'd be catch'd by some of the Family—and have my Nose cut off—or, any of the Neighbours shou'd observe me sauntering about here, and mistake me for a Thief, and send me to Newgate—or, some Drunken Fellow stumble upon me, and break my Bones— 'Od, methinks, I feel a Cudgel about my Ears already.
My Lord bid a me watch dis Door for a Shentleman's coming out, begar me believe it is some Rival—
Seeing him.Ah! one, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hun∣dred—oh, oh, oh.
Vat de Divel Noise is dat? I se no Body but my self mafoy—
Humph, ha,—I was mistaken, I think I see but one—I hope he's a Christian—I have a good mind to speak to him— I'll give him wondrous good Words—Pray, sweet Sir, do you want any thing hereabouts?
Ha! Vat de Divel is dat to you?
Nay, don't be so angry, gentle Sir, I, I, I, I, ask you for no harm indeed, not I.
You aske a me for no Harm, begar you be one Im∣pertinent Fellow, to aske a me vat I do want; suppose I do want nothing, vat den, ha!

Why, if you have no very great Business Sir, I shou'd be extreamly oblig'd to you, if you wou'd do me the Favour to quit this Street, Sir, because I have some small Affairs here— not of my own, I assure you, if they were you shou'd command me, but they are my Master's; now, Servants you know, Sir, must obey Orders.
Now you must know, Sir, I have Business of my Ma∣ster's too, therefore must stay Sir, and if you will take a my ad∣vice, go your self—begone—run.
Gently, good Sir, gently—I cannot run, for I am lame of one Leg.
Dis Fellow is one dam Coward, mafoy—Me vill exalt a me Voice Aside. Mortblue, me vill make a you lame of do toder Leg too, if you don't leave dis Street presently—
I do intend to leave the Street Sir, for I cannot carry it away upon my Shoulders.
A pox take a your Pun, I hate a your dam Scoundrel Wit begar.
Why, Sir, with Submission, you are but a Servant your self; you told me so just now.

A Servant! Begar me be de Gentleman to you—Me be de French Valet de Chambre to one Lord, and you be one Skipkennel mafoy in the Livery; the Frenchman scorn de Li∣very, as much as de Irish do de Trade.

'Egad, I'll try the Courage of this French Son of a Kickshaw—may be he loves fighting no more than I do, and if the worst come to the worst, that the Dog should be stout, I can but run away at last.Aside.
Garsoons, why don't a you go, Sir—What be you stding for, ha! Fripone?
I am thinking, Sir, that a French Valet makes the best Pimp in the World.
Pimp! Pimp a your self begar—de French a Man never Pimp—No, he taste always——Parblue, de English Lady, be tout jour at de French man Service.
I thought it was something indeed, that scatter'd the Pox about so plentifully—Are not you a Surgeon too, Monsieur Rgout?
Yes, Sir, every French man is by Nature, a Surgeon, Barber, and Dancing Master, mafoy.Cuts a Caper.

A Dancing Master! Ha, ha, ha, I thought as much, for I have seen your Country-men caper away before the Al∣lies many a time; and hark ye, Monsieur! If you don't march off, I will play you such an English Courant, of slap-dash, presently, that shan't out of your Ears this Twelvemonth. Faith he's as great a Coward as I am, I'll keep my Ground, if I can till my Master comes.Aside.
You play a me slap-dash! Begar you had best be ci∣vil——Terniblue, 'tis like a your English a Fashion—talk of the slap-dash to de Gentleman—
A Gentleman! How dare that Gentleman talk saucily to another Gentleman, better than himself?
Oh parblue! a Gentleman Footman.
Sirrah there are Gentleman Foot in my Country, that keep such Scoundrels as you to wipe their Shoes; and I have a good Mind to rip up your Paunch, and make a Frigasie of your Puddings, ye Dog.
Begar me was mistaken in dis Fellow; I must give him good Words, mafoy, or de English Beife and Pudin will be in my Guts, begar.Aside.
Who are you talking with, Le Front?
Ah! parblue, your Lordship come a propos.
So! here will be no staying for me I find: Who the Devil is this Lord?
Here be one lousie Footman dat will stay here in spight of my Teeth, mafoy.
A nitry Son of a Whore, who does he call lousie? this Dog wou'd have me murder'd now—What shall I do, if I stay not, my Master will beat me, and if I do stay this Loud will cut my Throat.Aside.
Hark'ee Sirrah, who are you, that you won't leave this Place?
Who, I not leave this Place, Sir! I'll leave it with all my Blood Sir, this Minute; the Devil watch for Timothy.
Begar me be very glad he is gone.Aside.
Well have you seen any Body come out of this House, Le Front?
Not one Soul me Lor—but me Lor—have a you fa la la la sings a Minuet dance a de Minuet vid de Lady, me Lord you understand me.
No, I was prevented; I believe by the Man I saw in the Garden.
Did not your Lordship kill him?
No, tis him I expect here.
Why where did your Lordship leave him?
In her Chamber.

Ha, ha, ha, a very good Jest mafoy, me warrant he is better employ'd, dan to come to sa, sa, wid your Lordship— he will have de duel vid de Lady first, parblue—me Lor take
my Advice, make use of de Stratagem, fight like de King of France, politickly; and when he comes out, let your Lordship's Foot∣men sieze him, and make a one Eunuch of him to supply Valen∣tine's Place in de Opera me Lor, begar dat will revenge your Lordship very well.
Away, Blockhead! I scorn to take Advantage of him— If a Gentleman he shall have fair play for his Life, therefore be gone and leave me, I hear some Body coming, I'll observe.
Vid all mine Heart mafoy, me no love fighting since Wounds were in Fashion, de Divel rides post upon de English Sword, quite thro' de Frenchman's Body, begar.Exit.
I lest my Man hereabouts; where can he be? Tim, Tim, —he's either gone to stuff his Guts now, or fallen fast asleep— sure Constantia's not come out.
PeepingWho can this be? he seems as if he waited here for some Body; perhaps 'tis he I want.
What's that? Sure I heard a Noise; Tim, hist, Tim, where are you, Sirrah?
Ha! I'll answer to the Call, and try what I can disco∣ver—Here, Sir, here.
Here, you Rascal! where have you been lurking? Have you seen Constantia, Sirrah?
No, Sir, no Body has appear'd yet—S'death, Con∣stantia! it must be him.
I have a Coach ready at the Corner of the Street to con∣vey her hence, and then you may sleep to Eternity, Sirrah.
To convey her hence! Lucky Discovery; I may spoil your Design perhaps.
Constantia above in the Balcony.Hist, hist, are you there my Love.
Lord and Bast. togetherYes my Angel, make haste, I'm ready to receive thee.
I come, I come.Exit.
How now Saucebox; who bid you answer?
He that dares return your Saucebox, Villain have I taught you!Lays hold on Bastion
Are you there, my Lord—I am ready for you; tho' I wish you had ta'en another time.Flings from him.
So do I, because now I wait to carry hence Constantia; you heard her say she was coming.
But not to you; have at you, the Justice of my Cause shall light my Sword to find a Ravisher's Heart.Draws.
And Love shall guide my Arm to disappoint thy Joys.
Come on, I am not used to fear.They fight off.

Sa, sa, sa, sa, me no like a dat Musick: If my Lor should kill a dat Gentleman now—why den far him well— but if dat Gentleman shou'd kill a me Lor, why if me had his Estate, he might go to de Devil, begar.
Where are you, my Life?
Ha! What's dat? de Lady call me her Life, she take a me for some Body—parblue, and she shall find a me some Body too; de French a Man be very good for de Lady.
Where are you, my Dear?Groping about.
Here, here, my Dear.Softly. She runs into his Arms, he kisses her eagerly. begar she kiss a purely.
Now we'll part no more.
No more? dat is too long mafoy; me please a you for one two three Hours very well—but forever!—Me beg a your Pardon for dat, Madam.
flings from him.Ah! who are you, Sir?
Me be one very pretty Playting for de Lady.
I ask your Pardon, Sir, I was mistaken—What Wret∣ches Hands have I fall'n into? Sure I did hear Bastion's Voice?
Mistaken—begar you must not be mistaken, Madam, for you have make a me one very good Stomach for de Woman, and begar me vili no starve, and de Vittles so near me.
Away Scoundrel; that for your Insolence.

STAGE.HI: Strikes him a Box on the Ear.

SP.P: De Divel take your Mutton Fist, Jerney blue, me have a good Mind to knock you down begar.
In my Conscience I believe him—sure Bastion was here, if not he won't be long; I'll slip back into the House— pray Heav'n I'm not discover'd.Exit.

De Divel how my Cheeks glow—you be one gran Salup, Mafoy, me will be revenge—What, be she gon?
now pox take her, she is nimble at both ends begar; de English be de dam uncivil Nation, here is nothing but de Foot, and de Finger—de French accost de Stranger, Toutjour avec de Complesane com, sa
Voter serviture Monsieur tres humblement;
The English kick a de Breech, and slap a de dents.Exit.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I. SCENE Continues.

SP.P: I Have drove from Tavern to Tavern, from Chocolate-House to Chocolate-House, but can hear nothing of my Lord Richlove, I fancy he is lurking somewhere about our House still—kind Fortune direct my Eyes to find him, then if Revenge forsake me I'll forgive him.

peeping.Sure this is Bastion! and yet my Fears alarm me so I know not what I had best to do; if I again mistake, it may be dangerous, yet if it shou'd be him, and I not meet him, what cou'd he think? he wou'd conclude I lov'd him not, and that wou'd break his Heart; therefore I'll on, Inclination's an undaunted Guide. Hist, hist.
Ha! Camilla's Door open, and a Signal given! what Intrigue has she on foot? I'll return it however. Hist, here, here.
softly.Where, where have you been, my Dear? in∣deed it was unkind to make me wait so long.
Find so long! Damnation.
Come let us retire least we be discover'd; if we shou'd, Bellvil wou'd pursue thee to Death, and me to Ruin.
I can hold no longer: You have mistook your Man, Madam—but if your Ladiship will inform me who he is, I'll conduct you to him, perfidious Woman——
Ah! my Brother! oh miserable me, what shall I say! ow I'm inevitably lost; sure some spightful Planet reigns this ight, destin'd by Fate to overthrow our Loves—
What! are you Thunder struck? is Bellvil's Presence such a Terror to you? speak, who was I taken for?
I, I, I, I, I, did, did, did, not, not, not—
Ha! thy Tongue is modest, and asham'd to utter the Foulness of thy purpose—Was this thy Love to me, trea∣cherous Camilla?
Camilla! nay then there are some hopes yet, his mi∣staking me for her, may favour my Escape.

If you learn to be tractable, one may endure you for a Husband; ay you wou'd make a Husband of me in∣deed, a tractable Monster, to fetch and carry, to jump over a Stick, or hold a Door—'Sdeath, that I Knew this lucky Villain, I'd thank him for my good deliverance—What, are you dumb with Guilt? nay, thou mayst well be so: Oh Sex curst from the Original, I'm now confirm'd in my Opini∣on, that there never was a Woman true—Inclination, Va∣nity, Interest or Curiosity, has still prevail'd upon their field: Natures, and he that trusts their faithless Vows, forfeits his Reason, and destroys his Peace.

So, now I have fortified my Courage with a Dram, I'll try if I can stand my Ground. Hickups. Egad methinks I cou'd fight an Elephant now; I fancy Cowardice is a kind of Ague, and there is nothing like Brandy to cure it.Hickups.
Ha! who's here? pray Heav'n it prove your Lover.
All the Stars forbid.Aside.

Who the Devil have we got yonder? I'm afraid, ol Tim, thy Master is here before thee; and if so, Tim Boy, thou wilt be swingingly corrected—odds my Life there's two thing I'll see what they are, I'm resolv'd.Goes up to Be
I am ready to sink with Apprehension, if 'tis I'm undone for ever.Aside.
So, so, then you are here, Sir, I'm glad on't with my Blood—
Are you so, Sir? This is some Scout, I perceive.
'Tis Bastion's Man, oh that I cou'd speak to him.
But, but, but, how did you escape my Lord, and his Regiment of Frenchmen? Afore George I had like to ha been pink'd out of my Life.
Ha! my Lord! I wish Bastion is not murder'd.
My Lord! wou'd I had met his Lordship: Confusion! What Dog is this?
Kind Fortune bring me some Relief.Aside.
Is this your Creature to convey you to the Arms of your Gallant, Madam?
Madam! ho, ho, have you got her then, od that's rare 'faith▪ I wish you much Joy, Madam; I just come from drink∣ing your Health in, in, in, right French Brandy, or the Rogue has cheated me damnably.
Rascal, Pander, Villian, beats him. Sirrah, whose Scoundrel are you?
Ah! poor Tim! but I shall take the Opportunity, and not stay to part you.Exit.
Zounds what Tartar's Mouth have I popt into?
Speak, Hang-dog—Who do you look for? And what business have you here?
I can never answer Questions in the middle of Blows, Sir,—for I have a sort of an Impediment in my Speech,Hickups. which holds great Communication with my Shoulders—
Have you so, Sirrah, then I'll break that Communicati∣on ye Dog; I'll make you answer me, Sirrah.
Castigation always shuts up my Mouth profoundly, Sir.
'Sdeath, answer me to the purpose, or I'll rip up a hun∣dred Mouths in you.Draws.

Ay, if you do, Sir, I'll be hang'd if I shall speak at e'er a one of them—ah Lord, a Sword, put it up, good Sir, put it up, o I shall swoon away—when my Mother was with Child of me, she was frighted at a naked Sword, and I never cou'd endure the sight of one since, oh, oh, oh, oh; I am very sick upon my Faith.
You Cowardly Rascal! say then who did you expect to meet here?
I cannot find Bellvil for my Life, nor hear of him no where.
Why, why, why, I expected to find my Master here, Sir
Ha! what's that?
And who is your Master, Sirrah?
'Tis Bellvil's Voice.
Why my Master is a Gentleman, Sir, I assure you.
A Gentleman, Sir, and has that Gentleman no Name? 'Sdeath don't trifle, Rascal.Slaps him with his Sword.
Name! look ye there now, that Sword has frighed his Name quite out of my Head, upon my Soul, Sir.
Find it again ye Dog, or this Moment is your last.
Ah! Murder! Murder!
How's this? Murder—in the name of Goodness what's the matter, Bellvil? What are you doing to the poor Fellow?
Oh you can find your Tongue now, Madam, in behalf of your Emissary.Turns to her.
Egad and I can find my Legs too; the Danger has fright∣ed the Brandy quite out of my Head, and now my Courage lies all in my Heels.Runs out.
My Emissary!

Yes, your Pander, the cursed Pander to your Inclina∣tion, but I'll be reveng'd on him however—Ha! What is he gone? Confound him—but no matter, I am not that Fool which you imagin'd—nor you the Woman I took you for; I'm not to be impos'd upon, Madam.

Sure you are distracted, Bellvil—What Imposition do you mean? Was it an Imposition to prevent your murder∣ing a poor Wretch—or, when your Passion's up, must you dis∣charge it upon all that comes in your way?
No Evasions, Madam, can excuse you; you wou'd not have me think I dreamt all this?
All what?

So! you are a Stranger to what's past, I warrant, you run into my Arms without design—Come let's retire, if we're discover'd Bellvil will pursue thee to Death, and me to Ruin— You did not say them words neither—no, you are innocent of all—and who this Fellow is that got drunk with drink∣ing your Health's as much unknown to you as the Cham of Tar∣tary.
You are directly in the right on't, for I am a Stranger to all your Accusations.
Thou hast an Assurance beyond all Parallel.

I suspect Constantia was the Woman, and she has mi∣stook her Brother for the Colonel, for that was certainly Timo∣thy
by his Cowardice: Pray, Sir, where did I speak them kind Words?

Positively that Question has struck me dumb—and from this moment I shall think it loss of time to converse with you—
You can't by all your Cunning clear your Fame,
Or e'er induce me to believe you more:
Thus I cancel every Vow I made you,
And with this Breath I drive the Tyrant Love away.

SP.L: So incredulous! so insolently bold!
Then 'tis time to assume the Pride of Innocence,
The strongest, surest Guard my Sex can boast.
Know Ingrate——
I equally scorn your Love, and base Aspersions,
You think your self commission'd to be rude,
And Nature form'd you for no other End
But to insult and ruin Womankind:
Your flattering Oaths, and endless Perjuries,
Are Tools you use to forward your Deceit.
But when you think you have us in your Pow'r,
You quit the Mask, and show the Man all o'er:
Happy is she that trusts you not too far,
Who can retreat, and pay you with Contempt.

SP.P: Right Woman! when no Excuses can be found, their best Sanctuary lies in Impudence.Aside.

SP.L: I smile to think of thy affected Freedom,
And read the Weakness of thy purpos'd Thought.
You, Coward like, now boast of what you'll do,
But cannot act the saucy Scene quite out:
Yes, I shall have you trembling at my Feet,
Begging Forgiveness from my injur'd Heart,
But I will use thee as thy Crime deserves:
As what I've said was credited by you,
st so much Pity shall you find from me:
'll teach your haughty Temper to submit,
And all your Sex shall own a Woman's Wit.Exit.

SP.P:
Arrogance we all know you have enough. Death and Hell, is it possible that she can date to deny her Falshood— d to my Face—just in the very Fact—she's the Epitome f Womankind—the very Quintessence of Treachery—Marry
her! no, 'tis safer to accompany with a Crocodile— nor from this Moment shall my Sister see her—she that can cater for her self so well, is of dangerous Conversation—my Father shall lock her up this Moment, 'till my Friend arives.

SP.L: When I was young, a Soldier and strong,
'Twas Musick to hear the Drums rattle;
But now I am old, and the Weather is cold,
My chiefest Delight is my Bottle.

SP.P: Ho, here's her Father strouling from the Tavern I sup∣pose, I'll avoid him.Going.

Who's that, that wou'd avoid me? ha! I never flinch'd in my Life, old Boy—and Faith I'll know who you are— Lays hold on Bellvil. Ha! Bellvil—why what wou'dst th shun thy Uncle, Boy? ha, the Devil's in these young Fellow when they are in Love—they hate the Company of every Body which are not infected with their Distemper—why what th camest out of my House now I warrant, didst thou not, ha?
No indeed, Sir, not I.

Come, come, young Man, don't lye for the matter— I am acquainted with your Pretensions, Camilla has told me all— she has ten thousand Pound Boy, that I can't hinder her of, and I shall leave her a Loaf when I die—and let her chuse for her se and welcome—but methinks, Kinsman, you might have made your Love known to me—why what man, Cousins ma couple for all their Affinity—I don't take it kindly, Bellvil, faith I done—why what, cou'd not we have smoak'd a Pipe and crack'd a Bottle together, and settled Matters in order for the cracking my Daughter's Ppkin, ha?
I don't understand you, Sir, I have nothing to say t your Daughter upon my word, Sir.
How! nothing to say to my Daughter; that's good I'faith——a sly young Rogue this, why I tell thee she has me into the Secret.
Ay, Sir, that may be—perhaps your Daughter let more Men into the Secret, than either you or I may kn of, old Gentleman.
Why what do you mean, ha? my Daughter let Me into her Secrets! you had best have a care what you say, yo Man, do you hear?

Look ye, Uncle, I have this Secret to tell you, that I care not if the whole Town were acquainted with every Secret about her—for that I never intend to marry her, is as true that I know her too well to make a Wife on.

oo well to make a Wife on! 'Sdeath ye Dog, you made a Whore of your Cousin, have you? Sirrah, Sirrah, if you have forc'd the Lines, e'en carry off the Baggage, you R——Zounds, old as I am I'll have a push with you yet, Draw, Sirrah, by the Scars of Hocstet I'll not remember thou t my Brother's Son, but use thee like a Frenchman, Sirrah—

But I shan't forget that you are my Father's Brother, Sir, nor will I fight you—therefore pray let your Hocstet Fury cool—go home and lock up your Daughter, that's your best Security; I assure you I shall never force any Lines be∣longing to your Family, nor so much as make the least Attempt upon her Cover'd Way—and so farewel, Uncle,Exit.

Here's a Dog now! Zounds, he shan't carry it off thus— by the Fame of Ramilly I'll have Satisfaction, if I follow him to the Indies— Not attempt my Daughter's Cover'd-Way— Bullets, Balls and Cannons, he shall make a Lodgment there in spight of all the Mines his Inconstancy can spring.Exit.

A Pox of this secular Prince of Darkness, the Con∣stable, there is no disputing with his Mirmidons; had it not been for his Authority, I shou'd have paid his Lordship for his untimely Attendance! A Curse of all Ill Luck, I fear Constan∣tia's lost by this unlucky Accident! What can she imagine? She must conclude me all that's Base, and think me most un∣worthy of her Love—Sure, Fate takes Pleasure still to cross my Hopes, and render my Endeavours vain — All is silent as the Grave; not the least Whisper of a Voice! Where can this Servant of mine be? Death, I could shake the Villain in∣to Atomes, if I had him.
No News of my Lor yet, begar.
Oh, are you come, Sirrah — How durst you stir from your Post, ye Dog?Beats him.

Post! Begar your Lorship post a me no where;
what do you beat a me for? De Divel be in all de Folks to Night, I tink.
Ha! I have fall'n foul upon some Lord's Servant, it seems.Aside.
I desire your Lorship discharge me; de Valet de Chamber can no digest a de Blow, mafoy.
Prithee get thee about thy Business, and don't trouble me with thy Jargon, I thought I had struck my own Servant, I am sorry for the Mistake.
What de Divel, are not you my Lor den? Pox take a your Servant—Parblue, my Lor shall know your gran Civility to his Gentleman.
Pray, what Lord do you serve, Pultroon?
Pultroon! Begar me no like his Compliment—Me serve a me Lor Richlove, Sir; what have you to say to him! ha! Sir?
Nothing Sir, only I beg the Favour of your Gentle∣manship, to carry him that, and that, and that, Sir.Kicks him.
A very fine Present, begar.
And tell him, he sent them, that would have sent his Lordship to the Devil to Night, if he had not been prevent∣ed.
Monsieur, begar me no like a de Mesage, you please to send a your own Servant, dat my Lor may return de Fa∣vour—Jrney blue, me hate a de English, more den de Turk, begar.
Do you dispute it, Mungril? Begone, or I shall give you twice as much
Me take a your word for dat, begar, me no stay for de proose.Exit.Enter on the other side Col. Merryman.
Who's this?

Where cou'd I miss this Rogue—'Od I'll find him e'er I sleep, if I Die for't. Runs against Col. Bastion. Ho, ho, have I found you? Draw, you young Dog, draw, or Ill Spitlock you like an Eel, Sirrah, not attempt my Daughter's Cover'd-way, quotha.
'Zdheart, who's this? Tis not sure Constantia's Father; what does he mean by Cover'd-way?
What's that you mutter, ha, Sir!
I suppose you mistake your Man Sir, pray whom do you seek?
Whom do I seek? Why I seek Belvill, Sir Roger Mery∣man's Son Sir—now if you be not him, I beg your Par∣don.
I thought you was mistaken, Sir, I am not him I as∣sure you. Sir—I think 'tis Col. Merryman.
The very same Sir—Who are you? ha! by your Voice you shou'd be Col. Bastion.
At your Service, Sir.
What my Hero! Why how dost thou do, Boy?
Pray what's the occasion of your Quarrel with your Kinsman?
Hang him, he's no Kinsman of mine, but no matter for that—Thereby hangs a Tale, which you must not know, Sir.
I am not over-curious, Colonel.
Shall we take a Bottle, my Boy?
Another time, Colonel, but at present I'm engag'd.
Some Female Assignation — I warrant; well I am a Well-wisher to the soft Sex still, tho' Age has Cashier'd the Pleasure—Success attend thee.Ex.
What can his Quarrel be with Bellvil? Is he a Stranger to his Love for Camilla?
So, I have dropp'd this old drunken Fellow at last; I met my Lord Richlove's Valet with a Link before him just now, perhaps his Lordship mayn't be far off.
SP.STAGE: Perceiving Colonel Bastion, runs and catches hold of him.
SP.P: Who are you, Sir, sculking so near this House?
Death, Sir, who are you that dare to ask that Questi∣on?They struggle together.
Nay struggle not, for I'll know who you are before you and I part. A Light, a Light, a Light there.
Here, Master.
Colonel! Is it you? I thought you had been on your Way to Flanders by this time: Where have you been poaching?

Ha! Constantia's Brother!—The Coach does not set out 'till six: I came now from the Rose, where with two or three honest Fellows I have been drinking a Farewel to old
England, and Success to the next Campaign. I had like to have had a Duel with Colonel Merryman, he took me for your Pray, Sir, what Quarrel have you with one another?
The natural Antipathy Age has to Youth, I know of none else—he was in his Cups, I suppose.
But who did you take me for?
Not for him I assure you; so a good Journey to you, Cap∣tain.Exit.

Thank you Sir—he's gone into his own House— What can the Meaning of this be! I must endeavour to see Ca∣milla▪ 'tis break of Day, an unseasonable Hour to visit a Lady, but the Impatience I am under of clearing my self to Constantia, will break in upon Ceremony at this time—Oh Fortune, be thou once propitious, and give me full Possession of my Love, or make me lose the Memory of her Charms.
Where shall I light you to, Master?
No where; be gone— ha!—Exit Link-boy. Co∣lonel Merryman and Lord Richlove in Conversation! I'll wave Revenge for once, and listen to the Consequence.Withdraws.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Col. Merryman and Lord Richlove.

SP.P: Why here has been strange Mistakes, my Lord! Shou'd you have carry'd off my Neice, say you?
Most certainly—It had not been prevented, as I told you.
Who could that Man be?
I wish I knew him, Colonel; I fancy it must be him her Brother designs her for.
He is not yet arriv'd, that I know of.
I think it very unnatural in Bellvil, to force Si∣ster's Inclinations, even against Father's Choice.
Hang him, my Lord, he's a perfect Humourist; I wish I could plague him a little—I hope I may credit your Lord∣ship's Assertion? You say my Neice Constantia really loves you, my Lord?

Upon my Honour, Colonel, she has met me in the Garden, admitted me privately into her Bed-Chamber, and I was to have carried her off this Night—If I can deceive this old Fellow, and draw him over to my Interest, I may chance to carry my Design yet.Aside.
Nay! if once a Woman admits a Man into her Bed Chamber, she has a Design of admitting him elsewhere that's certain—Well give me your Hand, my Lord, by the Honour Britain Ill serve you if I can.
Say you so? old Gentleman.Aside.

I thank you, Colonel; but how shall I see Constantia? for I doubt this last Accident has doubled Bellvil's Care; if I cou'd be introduc'd into the Family under some Disguise, we might find an Opportunity for her Escape.

Humph, Disguise, say you? What think you of a Gre∣cian now? Od, your Lordship wou'd make a jolly Grecian, and you shall sell Perfumes, Wash-Balls, Chocolate and so forth—I promised my Niece some Chocolate, and you shall go from me.
I like the Contrivance! But Colonel, your Quarrel with Bellvil may be an Obstacle in my way; suppose I shou'd meet with him, perhaps your Name wou'd not give me Admittance, what shall I do then?
