Right! We must send against that—Now I think on't, I'll introduce you my self— you are sure my Niece loves you and that you have my Brother's Consent, my Lord!
Most certainly, Colonel; I hope you don't think I'd impose upon you?
No Faith, my Lord, I hope you don't; therefore away, get the Dress, and the rest of the Perquisites, and fear nothing; I'll carry you into her Appartment, and leave you to make the Discovery—
Let me come there once, and then —

Ay, and then there will be such Coving and Billing, ha, ha, ha! well, well, I have had my Day, as Dryden says—and so speed your Love, I say. The very Thought of disappointing this young Dog's Design will give me equal Pleasure, my Lord, it will run through my Veins like the Joy of Victory: I'll expect you at my House, my Lord—Not marry my Daughter! Zounds he shall sweat beneath the Fascines of Matrimony, before I have done with him.
I'll wait on you with all the Speed possibly I can, Co∣lonel.Exeunt severally.

Here's a Villain now; he has impos'd upon Colonel Mer∣ryman, and hopes to carry his Design by Treachery, but I'll counterplot your Policy; first let me inform the Ladies of this, then I'll take Care of your Grecian Lordship.
Camilla in the Balcony.Who's at the Door?
'Tis Camilla's Voice.
Colonel!
The same.
Stay, I'll come down this Moment.Exit.
Pray Heav'n Constantia may be with her: I know not why; but methinks a Heaviness hangs on my Heart, that al∣most choaks my Speech.
Oh! Colonel, your Affairs wear an ill Face at pre∣sent. Was not you to have met my Cousin this Night?
I was, but by an Accident I saw her not.
Nay, there were more Accidents than one, I can tell you: She fell into her Brother's Hands, instead of yours.
Unfortunate! Into her Brother's Hands?
But by her coming out of my House, he mistook her for me; and after she had made her Escape—
Blest Sound! Did she escape undiscover'd? By what Miracle?
I know not, but undiscover'd I am sure she did; for I coming by accidentally, met the Shock of his Fury, he still charg∣ing me with what had happen'd— and poor Timothy felt the Ef∣fect on't too.
Hang him, Rascal, no Matter if his Bones had been broke, so that had been the worst.
The Mistake has created an eternal Quarrel between me and Bellvil; his Passion wou'd not let him hear Reason, not my Pride permit me to undeceive him.
I am unhappy every way; can you forgive my being the unfortunate Cause, Madam?

Let not that trouble you, Colonel; but think which way to free Constantia; for but now, as she was coming to me, her Brother surpriz'd her, and caus'd the Door between our Ap∣partments to be nail'd up.

Mischievous Turn of Fate—This is an unforeseen Shock, what shall I do now? If I shou'd kill this Lord, it can't advance my Cause—nor give me Entrance to my Love— Something must be thought on to convey me into the House. I have Business of moment to impart to you, and to my Dear Constantia; don't you think it possible to speak to her thro' the Door?
I believe it may, if you please to walk in we'll try: 'Tis broad Daylight; Heav'n send the Day prove more propi∣ous than the Night has done.Exit.
From thence we'll-take our Measures.

Q.L: I shall at least detect my Lord's Design,
And clear your Cause, whatever comes of mine.Exit.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I. SCENE Constantia 'sApartment.

SP.P: I'll observe my Cue, never fear it. Ha! my Bro∣ther!

How's this, talking thro' the Door?—Sister, if you valu'd your Reputation, you'd not take your Confinement ill, nor en∣deavour to hold a Correspondence thro' a Door, which I had Reasons for nailing up.
Then you ought to have let me into your Reasons, Brother, and not make my Father's House a Jail to me.

Bating Camilla, you shall have what Company you will; I lov'd her once—once did I say! alas I find I do so still, and therefore won't expose her; but be assur'd there is a Cause, yes, and a just one too, for my proceeding. I expect Sir Phi∣lip by the first fair Wind; when you are marry'd my Care is over, and you'll have Liberty to converse with who you please; then you may renew your Friendship, Sister, but not 'till then, I assure you.
Then I'm afraid we have taken leave for ever.
How, Constantia!

Nay frown not, Brother, you cannot force my Will: What Privilege has Nature given you? Why shou'd you dictate to my Heart, or point the Man that shou'd reign Lord of me? I must tell you, Sir, this ungenerous Action makes me look with Strangers Eyes upon you, and weakens much the Affe∣ctions of a Sister.

Most Heroically spoken——Now let me tell you something; this haughty Speech has such an awkward A, that it seems to be but just acquir'd; let me advise you, give the Study over, for Passion in your Sex, is like Vanity in ours, very unbecoming, and rarely conquers ought but Fools and Cowards—Look ye, Constantia, I am positively resolv'd to have the Knight for my Brother-in-Law; now he has to Sister, and I none but you, then judge how the Alliance must come.
within.Buy any British Cloth or Holland, Kenti Cambricks or Muslin—buy any fine Bone-Lace within?
Well, Brother, if Heav'n designs Sir Philip for my Husband, I must submit; if not, there will be some way found to make you do so; then let Time decide this Matter. Flrell!
With all my Heart.
within.Buy any British Cloth within?
Call that Scotchman, I want some Muslin.
Yes, Madam.Exit.

DIV3.STAGE: Flor. Re-enters with Tim. in a Scotch Pedler's Habit, with▪ Pack upon his Back.

SP.P: 'Tis plaguy heavy, Heav'n send me fairly rid of it.Aside.
Have you any very fine Muslin. Friend?
Yes in troth have I, Madam, the finest for yet use a aw South or North Briton.
Come into the next Room, and show it me.
Troth will I, Madam; he's no Briton, that wo not ga with a Bony Lass.Ex. Tim. and Const.

Here's a Letter for you, Sir; a Porter brought it, but said it requir'd no Answer—I resolve to clear the Mistake rnt him and Camilla, that I may get rid of him, in order to sine my Lord—for he is very generous, and the stricter he co∣fines my Lady, the better for his Lordship, provided I can but secure Bellvil; this Letter I hope will do't.Asi

reads.What's here! I wou'd not have you credit the less for coming from an unknown Hand, nor think your self the wrong if you ask Camilla's Pardon, for it was not be, it Constantia that run into your Arms last Night. Ha! Constan∣tia! Hell and Furies; has she then a Lover of her own? th jumps with what she said but now: How have I been impos
upon▪ Constantia! if it be so, how shall I see Camilla's Face, or dare to approach that injur'd Maid? if it were not Camilla, she me out of Camilla's House, that I am positive of, and therefore she must be privy to the Intrigue: Now I fear my Suspiions were but too true, it was my Sister which I saw, and to it Villain in the Mask was the very Man—oh that I knew him but—Zdeath how am I confounded! hark ye, Florella.
It takes as I wou'd have it.Aside.
Do you know any Gentleman that makes Pretensions to your Mistress?
Mum! I'll play my Cards sure, no Confession in forma panperis, he never Fees, and therefore shall know no more than will serve my turn—who I Sir? not I indeed, Sir.
You lye—this Letter says there is a Man she likes.
Why, Sir, do you think my Lady tells me who she likes? some pitiful mischief-making Villain now has done this, to bespatter my Lady's Fame.

Ah! this Jade has all her paces, true as Steel to her Mistress, there is nothing to be done this way, I'll to Camilla's, own my fault, ask her Pardon, and try by gentle means to find the truth: Go bid Tom draw the Nails of that Door again— I'll make my Visit that way.
Any way, so I am but rid of you.Going.
And do you hear, Lock the Street Door and bring me the Key, I'll prevent her Elopement, except she leaps the Win∣dow.Exit.
The Key! which way will my Lord get in then?Ex.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE draws and discovers Constantia and Timothy un∣coming the Pack, from whence comes out Colonel Bastion.

SP.P: Egad he has almost broke my Back—he is consumed heavy, considering he has not made a good Meal these three Month—Here, Madam, here's a charming piece of Cloth for your wear, here's Cambrick, Kentin and Callico for you, all in a Lo—oh would you were in a Holland Wrapper together.
Oh my Bastion! Do I hold thee in my Arms once more?

My Love, my Life, my dear Constantia, oh let us fie and tie that Knot, which keeps me ever here: Haste I conjure thee, by our mutual Love, let me convey thee hence this Mo∣ment now, else I fear thou never wilt be mine—
Not thine! By the most sacred Ties of Love, I ne'er will be another's.

Alas thou can'st not promise that—Fortune sel∣dom takes the juster Side, and faithful Lovers are not always happy: Then prithee suffer thy self to be carry'd out the same way I came in, now before your Uncle and that Lord arrives. I have taken care of a Parson that shall make us one for ever.
But how wilt thou get out then, undiscover'd?

I do not mean to do it; let me but secure thee, I'll stay on Purpose to confront that Villain, and see him punish'd as his Crimes deserve; then unsuspected still of loving thee, flie to this dear Bosom.
Well my Love thou shalt be obey'd; tho' 'tis an odd way to be roll'd up in a Pack; but I have read that Cleopatra did so, and sure I do not love thee less, than she did Caesar.
So, now I am to have her upon my Back; egad that's quite wrong tho'.
The Colonel here! and as I live Timothy the Scotch∣man—I wonder'd indeed she wanted to buy Muslins of a Pedlar.Aside.
Come be quick, my Love.
Ay, you may be as quick as you please, but the Street Door is lock'd up, and your Brother has taken the Key with him to Camilla's.
To Camilla's! why, is he gone thither, say you?
Unlucky Turn.—

Yes, Madam, and thro' your private Door too. Some Body sent him a Letter, what was in it I know not, but when he had read it, he ask'd me if I knew of any private Admirer you had, seem'd in a great Fury, snap'd me up, when I told him I did not, with You lye, you do. But I had too much Con∣cern for your Welfare, Madam, to betray the Colonel.
Too well I know thee, but 'tis not time yet to dear Accounts.Aside.
We are certainly betray'd, and Bellvill knows I love thee.
Then let him know it, I am a Gentleman, and scorn to quit my Pretensions, or disown 'em, tho' ten thousand Dan∣gers threaten'd me.
Oh the Devil, I shall be pedlar'd, with a Pox to me, by and by I fear.
And yet I know not why, but I wish that thou wert safe out of this House, methinks.
Hark, I hear a Noise, for Heav'ns sake don't let my Brother see you if possible; here, here, help, Tim. to make up your Pack again; Florella, shut that Door.

STAGE.HI: They seem to huddle up the Colonel, the Scene shuts.

SP.P: Nay, fly me not, Camilla, I own my Fault, and am con∣vinced that I have done you Wrong.

Away, away, stick to your first Resolution; you know my Cunning cannot clear my Fame, or e'er induce you to be∣lieve me more. Ha, ha, ha, sweet Sir, you see I have not given my self much Pain about it.

Nor do I expect you shou'd, Camilla. Passion has the same Power o'er the Minds of Men, that Clouds have over the Face of Day; it contracts the Prospect of our Reason, and makes our Judgment dark—but when the Storm is once discharg'd, each Faculty reduc'd, and Prudence takes her Seat again, our Thoughts return, and all our Senses cool, and we examine Matters with a different Air, and every thing has quite another look; then if we find we have been to blame, 'tis no Shame to own it, but ra∣ther argues the Greatness of a Soul capable to distinguish right.
This Reasoning had been well six Hours ago.

Can it have lost its Value in six Hours? Will not this Posture satisfie your Pride, for only that can make you slight me now: Oh Camilla I know thy Soul too well, to think six Hours can raze me from thy Heart. Thou art not fickle in thy Nature, no, thy Principles disdain that part of Woman; by those then I conjure the, tell what thou knowest of this Night's Mistake.
Rise, Bellvil; you have cunningly found the way to move me. By that honest Principle I swear you wrong'd me, I was not the Woman you surpriz'd.
Then I submit to what-ever Penance you'll impose— but one thing more! Was not my Sister she? ha.

How comes he to guess at her? What shall I say — I
must not own it. Aside. I know not that, for when I came I saw no Woman.
Ha! my Father; I wou'd not have you seen, 'till I have told him we are reconcil'd. Away, I'll follow you instantly, and tell you all I know of that Affair.
I shall expect my Angel with Impatience.Exit.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE draws and discovers the Pack upon a Table, Con∣stantia and Timothy by it.

SP.P: My Brother! Oh lye still my Love, or we are undone for ever.To the Colonel
O wo's me, her Brother! oh, oh, oh!
Oh good Tim. don't tremble so, you'll betray all.
How now, Sister, have you not done chaffering yet? I bring you good News, Camilla and I are Friends again, and she'll be here presently, I hope I have oblig'd you now. Here, who's there?
Take the Key, and open the Street Door, again.
Ah wou'd I were fairly out on't: What will become of me?
Indeed you have rejoyc'd me Brother, I was sure my Cousin cou'd not merit your Displeasure.
Has this Fellow any thing that's good? What does he sell? What ails him to shake and groan so?
No, nothing worth looking on —h has got the A∣gue, I think.
Getting his Pack.Ays, Sir, I have the tertian Ague; oh, oh!
Poor Fellow, set down thy Pack, and go to the Fire and warm thee.
No, no, Brother, let him go to an Ale-house and warm him; go, go, away with your Trumpery.
Look ye, Madam, don't disparige my Commodities; I have nothing in my Pack but what any Lady may wear, by my Sol, Madam.
Prithee Fellow don't prate to me, but begone.
I ganging as fast as I can, Madam.Reels against

DIV3.STAGE: Belvill, who claps up his Hand to save the Pack.

SP.P: Ha! 'tis a comical made up Pack as ever I saw, and feels ly, there may be more in this Pack than I am aware off Aside. Poor Fellow thou art but weak, why do you carry such a heavy load? come set it down, I'll buy something of the out of pure pity.Aside.
Now I am ruin'd past redemption.
Ah, methinks I feel a Sword quite thro' my Body.

STAGE.HI: Sets down his Pack upon the Table.

SP.P: Have you any good Lace for Ruffles?
ce, Sir! I, I, I, I, I, I, I have—no—Lace, Sir.
What! have you any fine Holland for Shirts, then?
Holland, Sir, yes, Sir; no, no, now I think on't, Sir, I sold the last piece I had at the next House: What will become of me?Aside.
He certainly will find the Colonell this Fellow's stam∣mering will betray my Love; what shall I say or do to hinder it?Aside.
Why what have you then? this Concern has a Meaning.
Indeed he has nothing that you will like, Brother.
That I believe.Aside.
No, Sir, I have nothing ye will like upon my Sol, Sir; when I have recruited my Stock Ise call again.

STAGE.HI: Goes to take up his Pack.

SP.P: Sirrah, I say I'll see what you have; now you are a Rogue, I believe, and don't come honestly by your Goods, so are asham'd to show them; open your Pack, ye Dog.
Ah, Tim, thou art a dead Man.Aside.
Give me liberty instantly, Sirrah, or I'll cut your Throat.
Ah!Shrieks.
As I suspected! Villain! beats him. have you brought Rogs into my House to Rob me.
Sir, I suffer no Man to Correct my Servant; I believe ou know I am no House-breaker, and am ready to give you hat Satisfaction you please.
Oh hold, you shall not sight.Interposes.
Colonel Bastion! no! you have softer Wars for him, I suppose: Confusion! is this your going for Harwich, Colonel?
Had I not stay'd to have been serviceable to your Fa∣mily, I had been gone, Sir.
Serviceable to my Family! which way, Sir, by debauch∣ing my Sister? hark ye, Sir, I desire you'll give me an account of this by and by in Hide Park.Puts up his Sword.
If I convince you not that my Design was honourable, and what you'll thank me for too before I leave your House, I'll not fail to meet you.Puts up his Sword.
On that condition I am cool.
Egad I'm all of a sweat, I'm sure, and shall never be cool again, I'm afraid.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Colonel Merryman, Lord Richlove like a Grecian, and La Front like a Salup Man, with a Pot.

SP.P: Now, Bellvil, let me intreat you to step with me into the next Room. Madam, you have your Cue.
Ay, ay, I warrant you.
What do you mean, Colonel?
Suspend your Curiosity but a Moment, and you'll know—Come along, Sirrah.To Tim.
Well, for once I will.
What the Devil's to be done now?Ex. Bast. Bel. and Tim.
There she is, my Lord; to her, to her, Man, show, show her all your fine Nicknacks. Odso, here's my Daughter, and her Father, but I'll take them off presently.

Neice, I promis'd you a present of Chocolate, I met a Grecian here that has extraordinary good he says, so I have brought him in; take as much as you will, Girl, I'll pay for't, or any thing else he sells.
Let me see, what have you?
Take him into the next Room, Neice, I don't desire to see what Conscience you Women have, but I'll pay for as much as you'll buy, Neice.
I thank you, Uncle: Well, come in here then.
What, mayn't I see what he has got too?
No, no, no, there's nothing for you to see, Child▪ therefore do you stay here; come, I'll treat my Brother and you with some Salup.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rog.
SP.P: Salup, what is that Salup? I have often seen this Fellow sauntering about Streets, and cou'd not imagine what he sold: What is it made on, you?To Le Front.
Meo speako Engliso Nono.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rog.
SP.P: What the Devil does he say now?
Why he tells you he speaks no English; he's an Ita∣lian.
Excellent—I'm afraid he'll change his Tone by and by: Come, give me a Dish.
Senior, Expleco meo whato sheo wanto.
Uno dasho de Salupo.Tim. sills Salup.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rog.
SP.P: This Italian is very vowelly, it runs much upon the o methinks.
No Fool like the old one.
within.Help, help! a Rape, a Rape!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rog.
SP.P: Ha, what's that, a Rape? what the Devil, has the Grecian fal'n foul of my Daughter?
How's this? I'm surpriz'd.
Oh de Devil baul her, I shall sound away, begar.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Bellvil dragging in the Lord, the Colonel with Constantia, and Timothy.

SP.P: Come along, Villain; if you're so warm, here's a Pump hard by shall cool you.
Have a care what you say, Sir, I am not a Person to be treated ignominiously.
My Lord Richlove! I am glad I have met you; tho' you deserve below a Scoundrel, yet I'll do you the Justice that belongs to your Quality.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rog.
SP.P: Hark ye, Brother, have you ta'en up pimping be∣fore the Peace? Methinks you might have found some other Fa∣mily to have given Hansel to your Trade.
Look ye, Brother, don't be saucy; if your Daughter admits a Man into her Bed-Chamber, and offers to run away with him, it is to be suppos'd Hansel may be given without a Pimp.
So, the Devil won't bate me an Inch, I see.
How's that, Sir?
I must clear the Colonel, he has been impos'd upon; but here's one can tell best how his Lordship came into the Bed-Chamber, since she show'd him the way.
So, my Business is done.
Your humble Servant, Mrs. Bawd? this House has no farther business with you, go troop.Gives her a Ki.
Then some other shall, Sir.
His Lordship may set you up for his Use.
I am so confounded I know not what to say.
How does your Lordship sell Chocolate a Pound? ha, ha, ha!

Zounds, I never had such a trick put upon me in my Life; he told me that my Neice was in Love with him, and that he had your Consent, and Bellvil only oppos'd him—my Lord, old as I am, you and I must talk this business over be∣hind Mountague House, we must faith.

Let me advise your Lordship to practise the Rules of Honour and Honesty more, or resign that Title which ought to inherit both—Well may the Vulgar break in upon the Laws, when they can plead Custom from the Great: People in your Sphere, shou'd set Presidents for Virtue, and not give Examples of Debauchery and Vice; the higher Men are plac'd, the more their Actions are in view; and those that scorn the poor Plebeian State, shou'd scorn their Crimes much more.
I'll meet your Lordship half an hour hence at Tor's, from whence we'll take Coach to a convenient Place, you un∣derstand me.Aside to Lor.
Yes, and will meet you too, Sir; so dam your Fami∣ly.Exit.
Hark ye, Friend, why don't you cry your Salup?

De Devil take her Jest, begar me must beg Pardon Falls on his Knees. Me be do very good Family in France, but de pavre Refuge for Religion, Mafoy thust do any ting for Bread, me be de Valet de Chambre to dat Divel of a Lord, but if you will forgive me, I will be your Footman, be∣gar.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rog.
SP.P: So, you can speak English now, Sirrah.
A Footman, ye French Dog—speak one contemptible Word of a Footman, Sirrah, and I'll beat your Furmity Ke about your Ears.
Well said, Tim.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rog.
SP.P: No, no, let him alone, we'll think of a Punish∣ment for him, I'll warrant you.
Me wish me were in France, begar me never give England the Honour of my Presence more.

Colonel, I now own my self oblig'd to you, and thank you for this Discovery: And Uncle I forgive you, and ask your Pardon, for any ill Manners I might be guilty of last Night: Camilla and I are reconcil'd, and I only want my Friend Sir Phil∣lip to compleat my Happiness. I would gladly have my Sister may'd on the same Day.
A Letter by the Post for you, Sir,Gives a Letter.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: Looks on the Letter.'Tis Sir Philip's Hand; I hope it brings News of his Arrival.
I hope not.
I dread the Consequence.
What's this! Dear Friend; I trust to that Name for Pardon—of an Action which I am guilty of—I am mar∣ry'd—Dam him, marry'd—
What puts you out of Humour, Belvill?
No new thing, Madam: The Falseness of a Friend, that's all; my Knight's marry'd.
The best News I have heard this Twelve-month.
O blest Sound! I told you Brother, if Heav'n design'd it not, there wou'd be ways found to cross it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rog.
SP.P: Is this your honourable Friend, Bellvil? Ha, ha, we have both been mistaken I find; therefore by my Consent, my Daughter shall chuse for her self for the future.
With all my Heart, I'll never concern my self about her more; I wou'd only ask you one Question, Sister; did not you mistake me this Morning?
I did indeed, Brother, and for this Gentleman; I take you at your Word, Sir, and crave your Blessing.
We want but that to make us truly blest.
So! There's a Turn I ne'er suspected —

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rog.
SP.P: This is something quick methinks — but take her, and bless you both.
Well said, Brother; he's a Man of Honour, faith, and my Neice has made a good Choice: Nephew, give me thy Hand —by every dead Frenchman I am proud of thy Alliance.
And I look upon this Day the happiest of my Life, if Bellvil will accept me for a Brother.
Yes, yes, Colonel, since I see how things have been ma∣nag'd, you have my Consent among the rest.
Now you oblige me truly, Bellvil—Cousin, I wish you Joy.
I wish you the same, Camilla.
Noble Colonel, me shou'd be very proud to be your Gentleman, mafoy.

Zounds, ye Dog, wou'd you supplant me that have un∣dergone the Slavery of the Courtship, and now the Harvest of Matrimony is ripe, wou'd you eat the Fruits of my Labour? 'Tis my Turn to be Gentleman, Sirrah, and I'll quit it for ne'er a French Son of a Whore in England—that has no more Courage than he has Aside. therefore strip, Sirrah, strip, the best Man take it.Begins to strip.

SP.L: Hold, hold, we'll have no Domestick.
Broils; you are grown as stout as Hercules,
But come, Tim; your Quarrel shall end in a Song.

DIV1.HEAD: A SONG, designed to have been Sung by Mr. Pack, in imitation of the Irish, who was prevented by a Cold.
DIV1.L: DEAR Brother dost hear the joyful News,
Our Master's caught i'th' Conjugal Noose;
Wanton young Cupid so well play'd his part too,
That Caelia's bright Eyes soon shot his Heart thro':
Then ow la wa let us be merry,
O nily wa let us be merry,
Ya hony Lee let us be merry,
And drink the Bride's Health in racy Canary.
Ya hony Lee, &c.
Fill other Glass, the Groom's Health take too;
Why shou'd we sleep since he must wake too?
Oh this Liquor falls short of those Charms
That our Master will taste in Caelia's bright Arms.
For Ow in we there will be Kisses,
O nily wa, and sweeter Blisses,
Ya hony Lee, their Eyes are rowling,
At each Kiss one takes t'other's Soul is,
Ya hony Lee, &c.
Wen Night's gone, and the Day is breaking,
Y csing Briac's in woful taking;
will knew what she's been doing,
A e Months show the end of weing:
wa, there will be puking,
O , and dismal looking,
Ya Lee, this comes of kissing,
they long to taste the Blessing.
ee.
Grance the Bantling produces,
e well again for Conjugal Ʋses,
se men is not the whole World's stering;
lawful, she laughs at their Jetring.
, if Spouse proves naughty.
O , of Wenching faulty,
Lee, what a peal she'll ring him,
Ad may Kisses must wipe off his Sinning!
a y Lee, &c.

SP.P: Very well.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rog.
SP.L: What think you of a Dance now?
Some of my Servants play on the Violin.

SP.P: Away with it then—A Country Dance.
Now my Constantia, Fortune smiles upon us, and gives me all in giving thee.

Q.L: Even Honour, Glory, Conquest, centers here,
And me it self submits to powerful Love.
Be y gen'rous Man like me carest,
Still love like me, and still like me be blest.

SP.L: May ev'ry brave Defender of our Isle
Be thus rewarded for his warlike Toil;
And after Sieges, Winter Camps and Storms,
May some kind Female take him to her Arms.

DIV1.HEAD: To his Illustrious Highness Prince EUGENE of Savoy.
DIV1.L: ONE Night with various Thoughts I musing lay,
Reflecting on the Business of the Day;
At length these words got Passage from my Breast,
And thus the Sadness of my Soul express'd.
Oh! when will Faction leave my Native Shore,
And Britons labour to be Slaves no more?
When shall true Merit meet with due Regard,
And Friends to France, be England's Foes declar'd?
That once perform'd, my Nation wou'd have Peace,
And all our Troubles and Distractions cease.
While thus I argu'd, Sleep did gently steal,
And in soft Slumbers all my Senses seal.
Straight I on Albion's chalky Cliffs was laid,
From whence I Neptune's spacious Realms survey'd;
When Lo! a Dolphin hasted to the Shore,
His Back a Triton of distinction bore,
Who chose for his Support a Mountain Wave,
And from a Coral Trump, he three loud Signals gave,
Alarm'd Britannia came the Cause to learn,
From whence the Courier, and of what concern:
To whom the Triton bow'd his Head, to show
How much all Nations to Britannia owe.
Then strait prepar'd his Embassie to tell,
While joyous Waves with Expectation swell.
From Neptune, Lord of all the wealthy Main,
I come, great Eugene's Entry to proclaim:
His out stretch'd Sails the Winds with Pleasure fill,
And ev'ry saucy Storm's commanded to be still.
The Nereids all around his Vessel play,
While Shoals of Tritons guard his liquid Way.
Advance, Britannia, to receive this Chief;
The Tyrant's Scourge, and the Opprest's Relief:
A nobler Weight thy Seas cou'd never boast,
Since they the Great, the Glorious William lost:
Such dauntless Courage, such a Free-born Mind
Alone are fit to succour Human-kind.
Thus spoke the Triton from his tow'ring Wave,
And this Command the pleas'd Britannia gave:
To great Augusta quick let Fame repair,
And speak the Loud Eugene's Arrival there.
On Thames fair Banks I quick as Thought was thrown,
Where Fam'd Augusta's stately Piles are shown:
Here I beheld a lovely Silvan Scene,
Nature renew'd, and ev'ry Bough was green:
Here tuneful Birds their choicest Notes prepare,
And Arromatick Scents fill'd all the Ambient Air;
Whn a bright Form expanded on the Wing,
Did to my Sense Surprize and Wonder bring.
Her Golden Tresses by the Wind were born,
And num'rous Eyes did ev'ry Part adorn:
A Scarlet Robe she had all spangled o'er,
A broider'd Cestos round her Waste she wore,
And in her Hand a golden Trumpet bore:
She litt, methought, yet seem'd to grow so high,
Her Head aspir'd to reach the distant Sky.
Streight with her Breath she blew a gladsome Sound,
And Eccho joyfully the Notes rebound.
Augusta heard, and rais'd her awful Head,
While Thamasis forsook his owzy Bed:
To welcome Fame they both appear'd in View,
And from her Looks propitious Omens drew.
Smiling she stood, and with a cheerful Voice
Cry'd, Hail old Thame, Augusta now rejoice,
Great Eugene comes, your Banners streight display,
From ev'ry Turret solemnize this Day.
To Minds like his—you all your Safeties owe,
From Souls enlarg'd your choicest Blessings flow.
Eugene and Marlbrô, Names to Europe dear,
True Heroes born, and Brothers of the War,
Their innate Worth immortal Life shall give,
And make their Fame in spight of Envy, Live,
And even the sharp, and Iron Teeth of Time
(That must destroy these Lofty Piles of thine)
Shall make their Actions much the brighter show
For those Immortal as their Souls shall grow.
Haste Britons, haste, your choicest Youth prepare
To meet, and entertain this God of War;
From him, and Marlbrô, let your Soldiers take
Such bright Example as true Heroes make.
Be brave like them, like them discharge their Trust,
To ANNE be Loyal, to their Country Just;
So shall their Acts strike Envy's Censure dumb,
And thus Britannia Rival ancient Rome.
So spoke the Goddess, and withdrew from Sight,
Hiding her fluid Form in Folds of Light.
Augusta hasted to display her Pride,
And Thame his Joys exprest with double Tide.
Now was each Street with Expectation fill'd,
When I a Train of Britons Pride beheld;
For Fancy here again had chang'd the Scene,
And ANNA's Court appear'd, to welcome Great Eugene.
Foremost in Worth, did Graceful Marlbrô stand,
Whose Wondrous Conduct sav'd the British Land,
And Europe's Ballance fix'd in ANNA's Hand.
Spight of his Foes, he's still to, Eugene dear
Who knows his Soul, knows ev'ry Virtue there,
Knows Loyalty and Courage fill his Breast,
And sees his Mind, with Truth, and Prudence drest.
Again his Fame shall glitter like a Star,
When England's Foes like Meteors disappear;
But now behold the lovely Eugene here.
And with him comes the Genius of our Isle,
Methinks I see her on the Heroes smile,
And hear her say, Go one Brave Pair, subdue
The Tyrant only can be crush'd by you.
Then Savoy's Hero singly thus addrest.
Hail valiant Prince, far more than Monarch blest;
He wants no Crown, who reigns in ev'ry Breast.
Thy Presence here my dropping Nation warms,
While Belgia owes her Being to thy Arms.
The barbarous Turk thy Conqu'ring Name reveres,
And more thy Sword, than Mahmet's Curse, he fears.
By thee, his chosen Troops were put to Flight,
Or cut to Pieces in their Sultan's Sight.
By thee was Savoy's Duke retriev'd from Fate,
His Foes by thee were beat, by thee he holds his State.
Hail, matchless Youth of the Soissonian Line,
Whose Actions Bright, as Roman Consuls shine:
Not more, the Macedonian Chief renown'd,
Nor he, who thro' the Alps a Passage found.
The Gallick Tyrant dreads thy vengeful Hand,
And sees his ill-got Trophies tott'ring stand;
Tho' freed from Marlbrô, still his Fears remain,
Still Anjou trembles on the Throne of Spain;
And if I ought foresee, the Bourbon Race
Shall forc'd by thee to Austria's House give place.
Thus Britain's Genius—while the list'ning Crowd
Exprest their Joys in Acclamations loud:
Shook with the Sound, Sleep loosen'd all his Ties,
And left me waking in a pleas'd Surprize.

DIV1.HEAD: The EPILOGUE design'd to have been spake the first Night by Mrs. Oldfield.
DIV1.L: IN these good Times when War i like to cease.
And Europe soon expects a gen'ral Peace;
Is Hesus Half-Wits, and Criticks, all may know
I frers Apollo come a Pleipo;
Who well inclin'd to treat, by me thinks fit
To send Proposals from the State of Wit;
Against such strong Consederates engag'd,
An unsuccessful War he long has wag'd;
And now declares, if you will all submit
To pay the Charges of his Box and Pit,
He will no more Hestelities commit.
In all their Works his Poets shall take Care
Never to represent you, at you are.
But on the Critick, Judgment shall bestow,
Sense on the Witling, Beauty on the Bea.
This for the Men; Next he assures the Fair,
He grieves this ever he with them made War;
Or ever in his Plays attack'd their Fame,
Or any thing disl'd unfit to name;
O Caracters of faithless Women drew,
And show'd frign'd Beauties, so unlike the true,
But in all future Scenes the Sex shall see
Themselves as charming as they wish to be;
For them he will ordain new Comick Rules,
And never more will make them do on Fols:
And when he rises to the Tragick Strain,
Noe but true Heroes shall their Favours gain;
Such as that Stranger who has grac'd our Land,
Of equal Fame for Council, and Command,
A Prince, whose Wisdom, Valour, and Success,
The gaving World with Acclamations bless;
By no great Captain in past Times outdone,
And in the present qual'd but by ONE.
These fair Conditions, will, I hope, compose
All Wars between the Poets and their Foes.
Come Sign the Peace, and let this happy Age
Produce a League in favour of the Stage:
But shou'd this fail, at least our Author prays
A Truce may be concluded for six Days.
